div.p: THE FALSE COUNT, OR, A New Way to play AN OLD GAME. As it is Acted at the Dukes Theatre.
LONDON, Printed by M. Flesher, for Jacob Tonson, at the Judge's-Head in Chancery-lane, near Fleetstreet. 1682.

lg.l: KNow all the Whiggs and Tories of the Pit,
(Ye furious Guelfs and Gibelines of Wit,
Who for the Cause, and crimes of Forty one
So furiously maintain the Quarrel on.)
Our Author as you'll find it writ in story,
Has hitherto been a most wicked Tory;
But now to th' joy o' th' Brethren be it spoken,
Our Sisters vain mistaking eyes are open;
And wisely valluing her dear interest now,
All powerfull Whiggs, converted is to you.
'Twas long she did maintain the Royal Cause,
Argu'd, disputed, rail'd with great applause;
Writ Madrigals and Dogerel on the times,
And charg'd you all with your fore-fathers crimes;
Nay confidently swore no plot was true,
But that so slyly carri'd on by you.
Rais'd horrid scandals on you, hellish stories,
In Conventicles how you eat young Tories;
As Jew did heretofore eat Christian suckling;
And brought an Odium on your pious gutling:
When this is all malice it self can say,
You for the good old Cause devoutly eat and pray:
Though this one Text were able to convert ye,
Ye needy tribe of scriblers to the Party;
Yet there are more advantages than these,
For write, invent, and make what Plots you please,
The Wicked Party keeps your Witnesses;
Like frugal Cuckold-makers you beget
Bratts that, secur'd, by others fires shall sit.
Your Conventicling miracles out doe
All that the Whore of Babylon e'er knew:
By wondrous art you make Rogues honest men,
And when you please transform 'em Rogues again.
To day a Saint, if he but hang a Papist,
Peach a true Protestant, your Saint's turn'd Atheist:
And dying Sacraments do less prevail,
Than living ones though took in Lamb's-Wool-Ale.
Who wou'd not then be for a Common-weal,
To have the Villain cover'd with his Zeal?
●… Zeal, which for convenience can dispence
With Plays, provided there's no wit nor sense;
For Wit's prophane, and Iesuitical,
And Plotting's Popery, and the Devil and all.
We then have fitted you with one to day,
'Tis writ as't were a recantation Play;
Renouncing all that has pretence to witty,
T' obleige the Reverend Brumighams o' th' City:
No smutty Scenes, no Iests to move your Laughters,
Nor Love that so debauches all your Daughters.
But shou'd the Toryes now, who will desert me
Because they find no dry bobs on your Party,
Resolve to hiss as late did Popish Crew,
By Yea and Nay, shee'll throw her self on you,
The grand bequest of Whiggs, to whom shee's true.
Then let 'em rail and hiss and damn their fill,
Your Verdict will be Ignoramus still.

list.item: Mr. 〈◊〉, Don Carlos, Governour of Cadez, young and rich, in love with Julia.
Mr. 〈◊〉, Antonio, A Merchant, young and rich, Friend to Carlos, in love with Clara, promis'd to Isabella.
Mr. Nokes, Francisco, Old and rich, Husband to Julia and Father to Isabella.
Mr. Bright, Baltazer, Father to Julia and Clara.
Mr. Freeman, S●…stian, Father to Antonio.
Mr. Underhill Guzman, Gentleman to Carlos.
Mr. Lee, Guiliom, A Chimney Sweeper; the False Count.
Two overgrown Pages to the False Count.

list.head: Women.
list.item: Mrs. Davis, Julia, Wife to Francisco; young and hansom, in love with Carlos.
Mrs. P●…y, Clara, Sister to Julia, in love with Antonio.
Mrs. Co●…, Isabella, Daughter to Francisco; proud, vain and foolish, despising all men under the degree of Quality, and falls in love with Guiliom.
Mrs. Osborn, Jacinta, Woman to Julia.

div.head: THE FALSE COUNT, OR, A New way to play AN OLD GAME.
ACT I.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: BY all that's good, I'm mad; stark raving mad, to
have a Woman young, rich, beautyfull,
Just on the point of yeilding to my Love,
Snatcht from my Armes by such a Beast as this;
An Old ridiculous Buffoon, past Pleasure,
Past Love, or any thing that tends that way;
Ill-favour'd, Ill-bread, and Ill-qualify'd,
With more Diseases than a Horse past Service;
And onely blest with Fortune and my Julia:
For him, I say, this Miser, to obtain her,
After my tedious nights and dayes of Love,
My midnight Watchings, Quarells, Wounds and Dangers;
— My Person not unhansom too,
By Heav'n, 'twas Wonderous strange!

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: And old Francisco, without the expence of an hours Courtship, a Billet Doux, or scarce a Sight of her, could gain her in a day; and yet 'tis wonder, your Fortune and your Quality, should be refus'd by Don Baltazer, her Father.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: A Pox upon't, I went the wrong way to work, and courted the Daughter, but indeed my Father, the late Governor of Cadez, whose Estate and Honour I now enjoy, was then living; and, fearing he would not consent to my Passion, I endeavor'd to keep it secret, though sacred Vows had past between us two.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Did she not tell you of this Marriage with old Francisco?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: The night before, she did; but onely by a Letter from her window dropt; which when by the help of a dark Lantern, I had read, I was struck dead with Grief.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Expect to morrow night to hear I'm dead, since the next Sun will guide me to a fatall Marriage with old Francisco. Your Julia.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Judge, dear Antonio, my Surprise and Grief;
A while I stood unmov'd, thoughtless, and silent,
But soon rage wak'd me to new Life again;
But what I said and did, I leave to raging Lovers,
Like disappointed me, to guess and judge;
She heard— and onely answer'd me in tears,
Nor could I beg one tender word from her,
She sight, and shut the window too, and vanisht.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And she accordingly next day was married.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: She was,— and I have since endeavor'd all the Arts and Ways I can, to Cuckold him; 'tis now two months since the Wedding, and I hear he keeps her as close as a Relict, jealous as Age and Impotence can make him.— She hitherto has been absent at Sivil, but Expectation of her Daughter-in-law's Wedding with you has brought 'em hither,— and, I ask your Pardon, Antonio, for rallying your Father-in-law that shall be, old Francisco.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: I hope you are mistaken, Sir.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: How, Are not you to marry his Daughter Isabella?

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p:
Not, if I can help it, Sir,— the Honour you have done me in your friendship to me, a Person so much above me in Title and Birth, makes me think it my Duty to conceal no part of my Heart to you,— Know then this Isabella, daughter to old
Francisco, and your Cuckold that shall be, I hope, is, though fair most ridiculously proud, vain and fantasticall; as all of her Birth and Education, grown Rich, are;

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Prethee, What was her Birth?

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Why, her Father, old Francisco, was in his youth an English Cordwinder, that is to say, a Shoo-maker, Which he improv'd in time to a Merchant, and, the Devil and his Knavery helping him to a considerable Estate, he set up for Gentleman; and being naturally a stingey, hide bound Rascall, and in the Humour of jealousie even out-doing the most rigid of us Spaniards, he came over into Spain, to settle with his whole Family, where, his Wife dying, to heighten the vice, marries this young Julia, your Mistress, Sir;— and now this Daughter of his having wholly forgot her originall Dunghill, setts up for a Vicountess at least, though her father has design'd me the Blessing; but I have fixt my Heart and Eyes elsewhere, Clara, the young Sister of your Mistress, Sir, commands my Liberty.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Clara, I've seen her, she has Youth and Beauty capable to make a conquest any where,— but, Does she know your Love?

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: She does; and makes me think my Love return'd.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Then know, Antonio, I must be your Rival.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: How, Sir!

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: You said but now you were my Friend, Antonio,
If true, you must assist in my design.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: I listen, Sir, impatiently.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Then thus; Before I knew she was your Mistress, I had resolv'd upon Adresses to her, in order to't, have treated with her Father about a Marriage.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: How! and wou'd the false, forsworn, receive your Vows!

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: No; but with Tears implores her Father dayly, when e'er he speaks to her about my Passion; nor can I undeceive her, for indeed I have but Feign'd a Love, (she living in the same house with Julia whilst here at Cadez) to get an opportunity with that dear, charming Creature; for, coming as a Brother, sure they'll admit me kindly; nor will Francisco, who has heard of what has past 'twixt me and Julia, suspect me any more.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: I knew I had a Rivall, Sir, which Clara lov'd not; but nere cou'd get it from her who he was, for fear of mischief— I have often the Liberty to see her, under the name and pretence of Isabella's Lover.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: And I Visit her onely to get a sight of Julia, which hitherto has been impossible, though I have oft indeavor'd it— I beg you'll not be jealous, for this, by Heav'n, is onely my Design.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: I'll trust my Life, my Honour and my Mistress, in so good hands at any time.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: You obliege me; but though I find your Clara, cold and cruel, Isabella would invite me to her Love, And makes so many kind advances to me.—

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: So would she for your Title were you deform'd, and had no shape of man about you; but me, because a little Citizen and Merchant— she so reviles, Calling me base Mechanick, Sawcy Fellow; and wonders where I got the Impudence to speak of Love to her,— in fine I am resolved to be reveng'd on all her Pride and Scorn; by Heav'n, I will invent some dire Revenge;— I'm bent upon't, and will about it instantly.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: — and would you do it home and hansomly— and have a good occasion of being disingag'd from her, and make her self the Instrument?

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Ay, such a Plot were worth the Prosecution.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: And such a one I have in my head, Guzman, my servant, knows a Fellow here in Cadez, whom for his pleasant humour I have oft observ'd, as I have past the streets, but too mean to be converst with, by almost any humane thing, by Trade, a Chimney Sweeper.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: On, Sir, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: This Fellow's of a quick Wit and good Apprehension, though possibly he cannot act the Don so well, yet that which makes up the best part of our young Gallants, now a days, he shall not want; that is, good Cloaths, Money, and an Equipage,— and a little Instruction will serve turn.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: I'm ravisht with the Fancy;— let me see— he shall be an English Lord, or a French Count.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Either, we'll furnish him with Bills on Seigniour Don Francisco,— men and bagage, and the business is done— he shall make Love to her.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Most Excellent.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Guzman, have you not observ'd this Fellow I am speaking off?

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p:
Observ'd him, Sir; I know him particulary, I'll fetch him
to you now, Sir; he alwaies stands for new employment with the rest of his Gang under Saint Jago's Church-wall.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Bring him anon to my Lodgings, where we'll prepare him for the Adventure.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: And if the Proud Isabella bite not at so gay a Bait, I'll be bound to marry her.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: And if she do not, possibly that may be your Fate— but, in return, you must let Clara know the Design I have, and, undeceiving her opinion of my Love, make her of our Party.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Trust my Friendship, Sir, and Management, I'll to her instantly, that is, make a Visit to Isabella, and get an opportunity to speak with Clara.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: And I must write a Letter to Julia, to undeceive her Fears too, cou'd I but get it to her.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: For that, let me alone—

div.head: SCENE II. A Chamber.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Lord, Madam, you are as melancholy as a sick Parrot.

sp.speaker: Juli.
sp.p: And can you blame me, Jacinta, have I not many Reasons to be sad; sirst, have I not lost the onely man on earth in Don Carlos, that I cou'd love? and worse than that, am married to a Thing, fit onely for his Tombe; a Brute, who wanting sense to Value me, treats me more like a Prisoner than a Wife,— and his Pretence is, because I should not see, nor hear from Don Carlos.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Wou'd I were in your room, Madam, I'd cut him out work enough I'd warrant him; and if he durst impose on me, i'faith I'd transform both his Shape and his manners; in short, I'd try what Woman-hood cou'd doe. And indeed, the revenge wou'd be so pleasant, I wou'd not be without a jealous Husband for all the world, and really, Madam, Don Carlos is so sweet a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Ay, but the Sin, Jacinta!

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: A' my Conscience Heav'n wou'd forgive it, for this match of yours, with old Francisco, was never made there.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Then if I wou'd, alas what oportunities have I, for I confess since his first Vows made him mine.—

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: — right— that lying with old Francisco is flat Adultery.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I might, with some Excuse, give my self away to Carlos— but oh, he's false, he takes unjustly all the Vows he paid me, And gives 'em to my Sister Clara now.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Indeed, that's something uncivil, Madam, if it be true.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: True! my Father has with joy consented to it, and he has leave, to visit her; and can I Live to see't? No, Mischief will ensue, my Love's too high, too Nicely true to brook Affronts like that.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Yet you sirst broke with him.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Not I, be witness heav'n with what reluctancy I fore't my breaking heart; and can I see, that charming Body in my Sisters Armes! that Mouth that has so oft sworn love to me, kist by anothers Lips! no, Jacinta, that night that gives him to another Woman, shall see him dead between the Charmers Armes. My life I hate, and when I live no more for Carlos, I'll cease to be at all, it is resolv'd.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, I hope to live to see a more Comicall end of your Amours— but see where your Amiable Spouse comes with Don Baltazer your Father!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: So— you two are damnable Close together, 'tis for no goodness I'll warrant, you have your trade betimes.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Meaning me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Yes you, one of my Wives evil Counsellors,— go, get you up both to your respective Chambers, go—

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: Barring your Complyments, good Son, give me leave to speak.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Shaw, I know as well as your self what you wou'd say now; you wou'd assure me I am Sole Master of your house, and may command; that you are heartily glad to see me at Cadez, and that you desire I wou'd resolve upon a weeks stay, or so; that you'll spare nothing for my entertainment, why I know all this, and therefore pray take my word, good Father in-Law, without any more adoe.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: Well Sir, pray answer me one Question, What drew you to Cadez?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
Why, I'll tell you; in the first place, a Pox of all Lovers, I say; for my Daughter Isabella is to be married, as you
know, to Antonio, a young rich merchant of this Town; in the second place, my Wife, with a Vengeance, must be gading to visit you and her sister, whom we heard was also to be married to the young Governor Don Carlos; 'tis shrewdly against my will, heav'n knows, for my witts are in an uprore already about this business— your Gallant's, Father, your young Gallant's,— I wish my Wife were secure at home again.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: Pray why so?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Alas, I see the Trick, Sir, a meer Trick put upon a man, a married man, and a married man to a hansom young woman,— you apprehend me.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: Not I, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Not, you Sir; why look ye; your young Governor who now is, made most desperate love to her who is now my Wife, d'ye mind me?— but you, being a man of an exact Judgment, to her great grief, gave her to me, who best deserv'd her, both for my civil Behaviour, and Comly Personage, d'ye understand me? but now this Carlos, by his Fathers death being made Governor, d'ye see? is to marry your other Daughter Clara, and to exasperate me, wou'd never let me be at quiet till he had got both of us hither to Cadez, to Grace his Wedding; a Pox of his Invitation, was I so civil to invite him to mine?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: If this be your Affliction, you may avoyd it.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: No, no, I'll try to force Nature a little, and be Civil, or so, but as soon as the Ceremony's over, I'll steal out of Town, whip a way, presto, i'faith.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: But sh'oud you do so rude a thing to your new Brother, your Wife wou'd think you were jealous of her. No, dissemble that Fault, I beseech you, 'twill make you odious to her and all the world, when 'tis needless; 'tis naturall for women to hate what they fear.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Say you so, then I will hide it as much as I can in words, I can dissemble too upon occasion.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: Let her remain awhile amongst us.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: The Devil a bit shee shall, good Father mine, no, no, I have more years than you, Sir Father, and understand what women are, especially when married to ancient men, and have the Conversation of young men— whose Eyes like Basilisks destroy Modesty with looking on 'em; the very thought on't has rais'd a Bump in my forehead already.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: I am sorry you shou'd suspect my Daughter's Vertue.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: May be you are, Sir,— but youth you know— opportunity— occasion— or so— there are Winks, and Nods, and Signes, and Twires— and— well in short I am satisfi'd, and they that are not may go whistle, and so I'll to my Wife, whom I have left too long alone, evil thoughts will grow upon her— Wife, Love— Duckling—

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: Wou'd I had never marryed her to this Sott.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Your pleasure, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Onely to see thee, Love.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I have a Sute to you.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: What i'st, my Chicken.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I Wou'd go make a Visit to my Aunt, my sister Clara's there, and I'll go setch her home.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Hum— perhaps the Governor's there too?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: What if he be? we ought to make him a Visit too who so kindly sent for us to Cadez.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: How! Make a Visit to the Governor? What have I to doe with the Governor, or what have you to doe with the Governor? you are no Souldier, Love! as for a Visit to your Aunt there's some reason in't, but for the Governor, think no more upon him, I say no more.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Since he's to marry my Sister, why shou'd you refuse him that Civility.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Your Sister, so much the worse.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: So much the worse?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I, so much the worse, I tell you, for, mark me, you have been Lovers lately; and old storyes may arise that are not yet forgotten; and haveing under the Cloak of a Husband both Sisters at command, one for a Wife, t'other for a Mistress, hoyte toyte, there will be mad work i'faith; What a Mixture of Brother by the Fathers side, and Uncle by the Mothers side there will be; Aunt by the Mothers side, and Sister by the fathers side; a man may sind as good kindred amongst a kenell of Beagles.— No, no, no Visits to the Governor, I beseech you, fair Madam.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: So, you are at your jealousie again.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Come, come, I love plain dealing; besides, when she Nam'd the Governor, Flesh and Blood could not contain.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I spoke in reference to his Quality.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: A Pox of your Civility; I tell you, I scorn my Wife should be Civil. Why, what a Coyle's here about a Governor? I'll stand to't, a man had better have a Mule to his Wife than a Woman, and 'twere easilyer govern'd.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: But, hear reason, Son.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: What, from a Woman, and a Wife? Lord, Lord, where are your Witts, good Father-i'-law? Why, what, a Devil, shall I be made ridiculous, a Coxcombe, Cuckold, to show my Wife? No, no, there's no Necessity of your Civility, Mistress; Leave that to me who understand the due Punctillio's of it.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: Harkey Son, harkey!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Father mine, every man to his business, I say, therefore say no more of this; For I'll give my Mother's Soul to the Devil, when any Wife of mine ever makes a Visit to the Governor; and there's an end on't. Was ever so horrid a Plot Contriv'd against her own Lawfull Husband? Visit the Governor, with a Pox.

sp.speaker: Bal,
sp.p: 'Tis an honour due to all men of his Rank.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I care not for that, my opinion is, my Wife's my slave, and let him keep his Rank to himself.

div.stage: Fran. gets his Wife behind him, and fences her with his Cloke.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: He's here, and with his Wife; How shall I doe to deliver my Letter to her?— Sir, by the order of my Master, Don Carlos, the Governor, I am commanded to come hither, to the end that, going from hence, and returning to my Master, I may be able to inform him—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: — That I am in health,— very well, I was afraid he wou'd have been harping upon my Wife in the first place— the Devil take her, she looks for't.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Farther, Sir, he kisses your hand, with a more than ordinary Friendship.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: A Pox of his complyments,—

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: But he charg'd me, Sir, most passionately to present his Service to your Lady.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Yes, yes; I thought as much.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: — In a more particular manner.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Friend, my Wife, or Lady, has no need of his service in a more particular manner, and so you may return it.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Indeed, but she has great need of his service in a very particular manner.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Sir, I ment no hurt, but 'tis all wayes the fashion of your true bred Courtier, to be more Ceremonious in his Civilities to Ladyes than Men;— and he desires to know how she does.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: How strong this Carlos smells of the Devil— friend, tell your Master she's very well, but since she was Married she has forgot her Gentile Civility and good manners, and never returns any Complements to men.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: — How shall I get it to her?— Sir, the Governor hopes he shall havethe Honour of entertaining you both at his house. He's impatient of your coming, and waits at home on purpose.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Friend, let your Master know we are here in very good quarters already, and he does us both too much Honour; and that if we have notice of the Wedding-day; and I have nothing else to doe, we'll Certainly wait on him, and the next morning we intend to take our leaves, which I send him word of before-hand to prevent surprise.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: But Sir,—
sp.stage: Aproching him he puts his Wife further.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Go, Sir, and deliver your message.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: But I have order, Sir,—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: There's no such thing in this world.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: I'm resolv'd to Teaze him, if I can do nothing else, in revenge;— But, Sir, he most earnestly desires to entertain your fair Lady in his own house,

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Yes, yes; I know he does; But I'll give him to the Devil first.— Troth, Sir, this Cadez Aire does not agree with my fair Lady, she has ventur'd out but once, and has got an Ague already.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Agues, Sir, are kind diseases, they allow of Truces and Cessations.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: No, no; She has no Cessation friend, her Ague takes her night and day, it shakes her most unmercyfully, and it shall shake her till the Wedding-day.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Were this Fellow to be try'd by a Jury of women, I would not be in's Coat to lye with his Lady.— What shall I doe to deliver this Letter,— Well Sir since I see you are so averse to what the Governor desires, I'll return— but, Sir, I must tell you, as a friend, a Secret; that to a man of your temper may concern you;— Sir,— he's— resolv'd when he Comes next to Visit his Mistress, to make another Visit to your Apartment, to your Lady too.
sp.stage: Goes to Whisper him, and gives Julia the Letter over his Shoulder.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Is he so, pray tell him he need not take that pains; there's no occasion for't; besides 'twill be but in vain; for the Doctors have prescrib'd her Silence and Lonelyness,— tis good against the Fit; How this damn'd Fellow of a Rival torments me; Honest Friend, adieu.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Now is this Fellow so affraid of being made a Cuckold that he fears his own shadow, and dares not go into his Wive's Chamber if the Son do but shine into the room.—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: So, your Mercury's gon; Lord, how, simply you look now, as if you knew nothing of the matter!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Matter, what matter, I heard the Civil Message the Governor sent, and the uncivil answer you return'd back.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Very good; Did that grieve your heart, alass what pitty 'twas I carried you not in my hand, presented you to him my self, and beg'd him to favour me so much to do my office a little for me, or the like; hah.—

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: And there's need enough, and the truth were known.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Well said, Madam.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Peace thou wicked Limbe of Satan— but for you, Gentle Woman, since you are so tarmagant, that your own Natural Husband cannot please you; who though I say it am as quiet a Bed-fellow, and sleep as sweetly, for one of my years, as any in Spain— I'll keep you to hard meat i'faith.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I find no fault with your Sleeping, 'tis the best quality you have a-Bed.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Why, so then, is the Devil in an unmercyfull woman? Come come, 'tis a good Tenant that payes once a quarter.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Of an hour do ye mean Sir.—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Peace, I say,— thou damnable Tormentor, this is the Doctrine you preach to your Mistress, but you shall do't in private, for I am resolv'd to lock ye both up, and carry the keys in my Pocket.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Well, I'm a wicked Creature to teaze thee so, Dear; but I'll doe what thou wilt; Come, come, be friends, I Vow, I care not for the Governor, not I, no more then I do for my— own soule.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Why so, this is somthing; Come, come your way's in,— who have we here a man, ad's my life away, away.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Yes, up to my Chamber, to write an answer to this dear Letter.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: No, 'tis not a man, but my daughter Isabella.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Now will I stay, and set her on to teaze the Doatard, wou'd I cou'd teaze him to death, that my Mistiess might be rid of him.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: How now, what makes you look so Scurvily to day? Sure the Devil rides once a day through a woman, that she may be sure to be inspir'd with some Ill qualities— what wou'd you have now?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Somthing.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Somthing; what thing; have I not provided you a Husband whom you are to marry within a day or too?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: There's a Husband indeed, pray keep him to your self, if you please; I'll marry none of him, I'll see him hang'd first.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Hay-day;— what is he not young and hansom enough forsooth?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Young and hansom; is there no more than that goes to the making up of a Husband?— Yes, there's Quality.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Quality;— Why, is he not one of the richest Merchants of his standing in all Cadez?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Merchant, a prety Character, a Woman of my Beauty, and 5. Thousand pound, marry a Merchant— a little, pety, dirtyheeld Merchant; faugh I'd rather live a Maid all dayes of my life, or be sent to a Nunnery, and that's Plague enough I'm sure.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Have a care of a Nunnery, least he take you at your word.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I wou'd not for the World, no, Jacinta, when ever thou seest me in Holy orders, the World will be at an end.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Merchant, why, What Husband do you expect!

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: A Cavalier at least, if not a Nobleman.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: A Noble man, marry come-up; your Father, Huswife, meaning my self, was a Leather-seller at first, till, growing rich, I set up for a Merchant, and left that Mechanick trade; and since turn'd Gentleman; and heav'n blest my endeavours so as I have an estate for a Spanish Grandee; and, Are you so proud, forsooth, that a Merchant wont down with you, but you must be gaping after a Cap and Feather, a silver Sword with a more dredfull Ribon at the hilt? Come, come, I fear me, Huswife, you are one that pusss her up with pride thus;— but lay, thy hand upon thy Conscience now.—

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Who, I Sir; No no, Sir, I am for Marrying her out of hand to any reasonable Husband, except a Merchant; for Maids will Long, and that's Probatum est against the pervailing Distemper of Longing; Hitherto I dare answer for her, but Batteries will be made, and I dare not be alwayes responsable for frail Mortality.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Well, I have provided her one that I like, but if she be so squemish, let her fast, with a Murrain to her.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Dear Father.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Dear me no Deares: Wou'd your old Mother were alive, she wou'd a Strapt your Iusticore, for puleing after Cavaliers and Noble men, i'faith, that wou'd shee; A Citizen's Daughter and wou'd be a Madona, in good time.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Why, Father; the Gentry and Nobility now adayes frequently marry Citizen's Daughters.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Come, come, Mistress, I got by the City, and I love and honour the City; I confess 'tis the fashion now adayes, if a Citizen get but a little money, one goes to building houses, and brick walls; another must buy an Office for his Son; a third hoysts up his Daughter's Topsail, and flaunts it a way, much above her Breeding; and these things make so many break, and Cause the decay of Trading; but I'm for the honest Dutch way of breeding their Children, according to their Fathers Calling.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: That's very hard, because you are a Laborious, Ill-bread Trades-man, I must be bound to be a mean Citizen's Wife.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Why, what are you better then I, forsooth, that you must be a Lady, and have your Peticoats lac'd four Storyes high; wear your false Towers, and Coole your self with your Spanish Fan? Come, come, Baggage, wear me your best Cloaths a Sundays, and brush 'em up a Munday Mornings, and follow your needle all the week after, that was your good old Mother's way, and your Grand-mother's before her; and as for the Husband, take no care about it, I have design'd it, Antonio, and Antonio you are like to wed, or beat the hoof, Gentle woman, or turn poor Clare, and die a Begging-Nun, and there's an end on't— see where he comes— I'll leave you to ponder upon the business.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: what, in Tears, Isabella, what is't can force that tribute from your Eyes?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: A Trifle, hardly worth the nam●…ing, your self—

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Do I, pray, for what sin of mine must your fair Eyes be punisht?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: For the sin of your Odious Addresses to me, I have told you my mind often enough, methinks your Equals shou'd be sitter for you, and sute more with your Plebean Humour.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: My Equals, 'Tis True, you're fair, but if there be any inequality in our births, the advantage is on my side.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Sawcie Impertinent, you show your City breeding, you understand what's due to Ladys, you understand your Pen and Ink how to count your dirty money, trudg to and fro chasfering of base commodities, and cuzening those you deal with, till you sweat and stink again like an o're heated Cook; faugh, I smell him hither.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: I must confess I'm not perfum'd as you are, to stifle Stinks you commonly have by Nature; but I have wholsom, clenly Linen on; and for my Habit, wore I but a Sword, I see no difference between your Don and me, onely, perhaps, he knows less how to use it.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Ah, Name not a Don, the very sound from the mouth of a little Cit is disagreeable— Bargain and Sale, Bills, Money, Traffick, Trade, are words become you better.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Well-said, use him scurvily, that Mrs. Clara may have him.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: The best of those you think I shou'd not name, dare hardly tell me this.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Good Lord, you think your self a very fine Fellow now, and finicall your self up to be thought so, but there's as much difference between a Citizen and a true bred Cavalier.—

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: As between you and a true bred Woman of Honour.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, you rail, and you may, long enough, before you rail me out of my Opinion, whilest there are Dons with Coaches and fine Lackey's, and I have Youth and Beauty, with a Fortune able to merit one, so farewell Cit.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Farewell, proud Fool.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Sir, be this evening at the door, Dona Clara has somthing to say to you.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Bless thee for this Tidings, dear Jacinta.
sp.l: — I find let man be Brave, or good, or wise,
His Vertue gains no Smiels from Womens Eyes.
Tis the gay Fool alone that takes the Heart,
Foppery and Finery, still guide the Dart.

div.head: SCENE I. A Chamber.
div.stage: Enter Jacinta with a Light, and Julia.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: WELL, Madam, have you writ to Don Carlos?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: No, nor is it possible I shou'd, this Devil haunts me so from room to room, Like my evil Genius to prevent that good; oh, for an opportunity of one kind Minute, to return Acknowledgments for this kind Letter he has sent me.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I'm glad you find me a Sybill; Madam, I ever proficy'd a happier end of that Amour than your ill fortune has hitherto promised,— but what said the Lovely Cavalier?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: All that a man inspir'd with Love cou'd say, All that was soft and Charming.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Nay, I believe his Art.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Judge then what my Heart Feels, who, like a fire but lightly cover'd o're with the cold Ashes of Despair, with the least blast, breaks out into a flame; I burn, I burn, Jacinta, and onely Charming Carlos can alay my Pain— but how, Ay there's the question?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Some way I will contrive to speak with him, for he has lost his old wont if he traverse not the street where you live, but see Dona Clara.—

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Hah, my Sister, whom yet my jealous heart can scarce be reconcil'd to; so deeply was my fear of Rivalship fixt there,— so sad, my Sister, and so near the happy day with Carlos?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
'Tis pity she that thinks it so, shou'd want him; the Blessing's thrown away on me, but we are both unhappy to be
matcht to those we cannot love; Carlos, though young, gay, hansome, witty, rich; I hate as much as you the old Francisco; for since I cannot Marry my Antonio, both Youth and Beauty are but lost on me, And Age decrepid wou'd be equal torment.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Wou'd Carlos knew your heart, sure he'd decline, for he has too much Honor, to compell a Maid to yeild that loves him not.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: 'Tis true, he is above me every way, and the Honor my Father thinks to do our Family by this Match, makes him resolve upon 't; but I have given my Vows to young Antonio.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: And young Antonio you are like to have, for any thing that Carlos cares; for know, to thy eternall joy, my Clara, he has but feign'd to thee, as much as thy Antonio to Isabella.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: But are you sure of this?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Most certain, this Night if you can let Antonio see you, he'll tell you all the Cheat, and beg your Pardon.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Which he will soon obtain, and in return, what Service I can render him, in your behalf, he shall not want.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Antonio will engage you they are friends.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: You amaze me.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I have appointed him this night to wait, and, if possible, I wou'd get him a Minutes time with you.

sp.speaker: Cla,
sp.p: Dear Jacinta, thou art the kindest Maid.—

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Hang't, why shou'd we young Women pine and Languish for what our own Natural invention may procure us; let us three lay our heads together, and if Machavil, with all his Politicks, can out-witt us, 'tis pity but we all lead Apes in Hell, and dy'd without the Jewish blessing of consolation.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: No more, here comes the Dragon.—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: So; together Consulting and Contriving.—

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: What, are you jealous of the Peticoat?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Peticoat, Come, come, Mistress Pert, I have known as Much danger hid under a Peticoat, as a Pair of Breeches. I have heard of two Women that Married each other— oh abominable, as if there were so Prodigious a Scarcity of Christian Man's Flesh.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p:
No, the market's well enough stor'd, thanks be praised,
might every woman be afforded a reasonable Alowance.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Peace, I say, thou Imp of Lucifer; wou'd thou hadst thy Bellyfull, that I might be fairly rid of thee— go get you up to your Chamber, and, d'ye hear, stirr not from thence, on pain of our severe displeasure, for I am sent for in all haste to signior Don Sebastians, 'tis but hard by, I shall soon return;— what are you here—

I have a high commendations of your fine behaviour, Gentlewoman, to Antonio; his Father has sent for me, and I shall know all anon, this shall but hasten your Wedding, Huswife, I tell you that, and so Farewell to you,—

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Say you so, then tis time for me to look about me.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: But will you go out so late Love! indeed, some hurt will come to thee.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: No, look ye, I go Arm'd
sp.stage: Shows his Girdle round with Pistolls.
sp.p: Go get you to your Chambers.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I wonder where this man of mine shou'd be, whom I sent this evening with my letter to Julia, what art thou?

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: My Lord, 'tis I, your trusty Trojan, Guzman,— what makes you here, Sir, so near the dore of your Mistress?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: To wait my doom; what Tidings hast thou Guzman!

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Why, Sir, I went as you directed me, to Don Baltazer's.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: And didst thou deliver it?

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: And the first thing I mett with was old Francisco.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: So.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p:
To whom I civily adrest my self— told him, you presen ted your Service to him,— sent to know how his Lady and he did. Which word Lady I no sooner nam'd, but I thought he wou'd have saluted me with a Cudgell,— in sine, observing her behind him, whom he shelter'd all he cou'd with his Cloke, I, taking an occa sion to wisper him, gave it her over his shoulder,
whilst she return'd some smiles and looks of joy,— but for an answer, 'twas impossible to get the least sign of one.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: No matter, that joy was evident, she wisht me one, and by the first opportunity my diligent waiting will be recompenc'd; but, where hast thou been all this while?

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Finding out the Chimney-sweeper, you spoke of Sir, and whom you order'd me to bring this Evening.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: And hast thou found him?

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: He's here, at the corner of the Street, I'll call him.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I have, Antonio, besides your particular Revenge, one of my own to Act by this deceit, since all my Industry to see the charming Julia has hitherto been vain, I have resolv'd upon a new project, if this False Count pass upon 'em, as I doubt not but he will, and that he gets admittance into the House, I'll pass for one of his Domestiques.

div.stage: Page holding his Lanthorn to his face.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Here's the fellow, Sir.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Fellow, he may be the Devil's fellow by his countenance.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Come nearer Friend; dost think thou canst manage a Plot well?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: As any man in Cadez, Sir, with good instructions.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: That thou shalt have, thou art apprehensive.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: So, so, I have a pretty memory for mischief.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Hast thou Assurance and Courage?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: To kill the honestest man in Spain, if I be well paid.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: That thou shalt be.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: I ll doe't, say no more, I'll doe't.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: But canst thou swear stoutly, & lye handsomly?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Prettily, by Nature Sir, but with good instructions I shall improve; I thank Heav'n I have Dossety, or so.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Thou want'st not confidence.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: No, nor impudence neither; how should a man live in this wicked world without that Talent.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Then know our Design is onely Comical, though if you manage not matters well, it may prove Tragical to you; in fine dost think thou canst personate a Lord?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: A Lord, marry that's a hard question, but what sort of a Lord?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Why any Lord.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: That I cannot doe, but I can doe some sort of a Lord, as some Lords are wiser than other-some; there is your witty Lord,— him I defie; your wise Lord, that is to say, your knavish Lord, him I renounce; then there's your Politique Lord, him I wou'd have hang'd;— then there 's your foolish Lord, let him follow the Polititian; then there's your Brisk, Pert, Noysey Lord, and such a small insignificant Fiend I care not if I am possest with; I shall deal well enough with a Devil of his capacity.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Very well, then there needs no more but that you go along with my man to my house, my authority shall secure you from all the injuries that shall accrue from a discovery, but I hope none will happen: Equipage, cloaths and money we'll furnish you with,— go home with him and dress, and practise the Don, till we come, who will give you ample instructions what to doe.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: And if I do not fit you with a Don better than Don De'll, Phobos, or Don Quixote, let me be hang'd up for the Sign of the Black Boy on my own Poles at a Spanish Inn dore.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: We'll be with you presently.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: And if you find me not en Cavalier, say Cloaths, Garniture, Points and Feathers have lost their Power of making one.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Hah, the dore opens, and surely 'tis a Woman that advances, dear Antonio, wait a little farther;— who's there?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Hah, if it shou'd be old Francisco now.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Let it be who it will, I'll tell my name, it cannot injure either;— I'm Carlos, who are you?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: A thing that looks for him you name— Jacinta;— are you alone?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Never since Julia did possess my heart; what news my dearest messenger of Love? what may I hope?—

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: All that the kindest Mistress can bestow,
If Carlos loves, and still will keep his Vows.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Julia my Life, my Soul, what happy Stars
Conspir'd to give me this dear lucky minute?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Those that conducted old Francisco out,
And will too soon return him back again;
I dare not stay to hear thy love or chiding,
Both which have power to charm, since both proceed
From a kind heart, that's mine.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Oh, take not this dear Body from my Arms,
For if you do, my Soul will follow it.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: What wouldst thou have me doe?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Be wondrous kind, be lavish of thy Heart,
Be generous in thy Love, and give me all.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Oh Heavens! what mean you? I shall dye with fear.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Fear, let coward Lovers fear, who love by halves,
We that intirely Love are bold in passion,
Like Souldiers fir'd with glory dread no danger.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: But should we be unthrifty in our Loves,
And for one moment's joy give all away,
And be hereafter damn'd to pine at distance?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Mistaken Miser, Love like Money put
Into good hands increases every day,
Still as you trust me, still the Summ amounts,
Put me not off with promise of to morrow,
To morrow will take care for new delights,
Why shou'd that rob us of a present one?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Ah Carlos!
How sondly do I listen to thy words,
And fain would chide, and fain would boast my Vertue,
But mightier Love laughs at those poor delays;
And I should doubtless give you all your Julia,
Did not my fear prevent my kinder business;
— And should Francisco come and find me absent,
Or take thee with me, we were lost, my Carlos.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: When then, my Julia shall we meet again?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: You Spaniards are a jealous Nation, But in this English Spaniard old Francisco, That mad passion's doubled; wholly deprives him of his Sense, and turnes his Nature Brute; wou'd he but trust me onely with my Woman, I wou'd contrive some way to see my Carlos.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: 'Tis certain, Julia, that thou must be mine.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Or I must dye, my Carlos.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: — I'm sure 'tis Carlos's voice, and with a woman;
And though he be my Rival but in Jest,
I have a natural curiosity to see who 'tis he entertains.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Oh Heavens! Sir, here's Francisco; step aside
Least mischief shou'd befall you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Now Love and wild desire prompt me to kill this happy Rival,— he's old, and can't be long in his arrears to Nature.— What if I paid the debt?
One single push wou'd do't, and Julia's mine;— but hang't Adultery is a less sin than Murther, and I will wait my Fortune—

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Where are you,— Don Carlos?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Who's there, Antonio? I took thee for my Rival, and ten to one but I had done thy business.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: I heard ye talking, and believ'd you safe, and came in hopes to get a little time to speak to Clara in;— hah!— Jacinta—

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Who's there, Antonio?

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: The same; may I not speak with Clare?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Come in, she's here.—

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: And prethee, dear Jacinta, let me have one word with Julia more, she need not fear surprise; just at the dore let me but kiss her hand.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I'll see if I can bring her.—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: A proud ungracious Flurt,— a Lord with a Pox, here's a fine business i'faith, that she should be her own Carver,— well I'll home, and thunder her together with a vengeance.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Who's here? sure this is he indeed; I'll step aside, least my being seen give him an occasion of jealousie, and make him affront his Wife.
sp.stage: [Goes aside as Fran. was going in.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Hum, what have we here, a woman?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Heavens! what, not gone yet, my Dear?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: So, so, 'tis my confounded wife, who expecting some body wou'd have me gone now.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Are you not satisfied with all I've said,
With all the vows I've made,
Which here anew, in sight of Heaven, I breath?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Yes, yes, you can promise fair, but hang him that trusts ye.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Go, go, and pray be satisfied of my eternal love.—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: How fain she'd have me gone now; ah subtil Serpent, is not this plain demonstration,— I shall murther her, I find the Devil great with me.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: — What is't thou pawsest on?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: The wicked dissimulation of villainous woman.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Francisco.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Oh thou monster of Ingratitude, have I caught thee? You'd have me gone, wou'd ye? ay, to Heaven, I believe, like a wicked woman as you are, so you were rid of me.— go,— and be satisfied of my eternal love,— ah, Gipsey,— no, Gentlewoman, I am a tuff bit, and will hold you tugging till your heart ake.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Why, was there such hurt in desireing you to go, that you might make hast back again,— oh my fears!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: That you might receive a lover,— 'tis plain— and my indignation's high.—

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Heav'n knows I meant—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Onely to Cuckold me a little,— get you in,— where I will swear thee by Bell, Book and Candle,— get you in, I say,— go, go,— I'll watch for your Lover, and tell him how unkind he was to stay so long, I will.—
sp.stage: Ex. Julia, he stands just in the dore, Carlos advances.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I hear no noise, sure 'twas he,— and he's gone in— To reap those joys he knows not how to value, And I must languish for; I'll stay a little— perhaps Jacinta may return again, for any thing belonging to my Julia is dear, even to my Soul.
sp.stage: [Goes just to the dore, Fran. bolts out on him.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: who's there?— what wou'd you have?— who wou'd you speak to?— who do you come from?— and what's your business?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Hah, 'tis the Sot himself;— my name is Carlos.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Carlos, what father of Belzibub sent him hither,— a plain case;— I'll murther her out of hand.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: — And I wou'd speak to any body, Friend, that belongs to the fair Clara,— if you are any of this house.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
Onely the Cuckold of the house, that's all;— my
name, Sir, is Francisco; but you, perhaps, are better acquainted with my Wife.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Francisco, let me imbrace you, my Noble Brother, And chide you, that you wou'd not Visit me.
sp.stage: Going to imbrace him, he flies off.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: And bring my Wife along with me.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Both had been wellcome— and all I have, you shou'd Command.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: For my Wife's sake— what if I shou'd Pistoll him now;— and I am damnably provokt to't, had I but Courage to shoot off one.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: — Methinks you make not so kind returns as my Friendship to you, and the Alliance shall be between us, deserves.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I am somthing Ill-bred I confess, Sir;— 'tis dark, and if I shou'd do't no body wou'd know 'twas I.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I fear there's some misunderstanding between us, pray let us go in a while, I'll talk you from your error.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Between us, Sir, oh Lord, not in the least, Sir, I love and Honour you, so heartily— I'd be content to give you to the Devil; but the noyse of the Pistoll wou'd discover the business.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: — Come let's in, and talk a while.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I'm sorry I cannot do't, Sir, we are something incommoded being not at our own house.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Brother, I am afraid you are a little inclin'd to be jealous, that will destroy all friendship.—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: So, how finely the Devil begins to insinuate?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: — that makes a Hell of the Heav'n of Love, and those very pains you fear, are less tormenting than that fear; what say you, Brother, is't not so with you?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: — I find you wou'd have me turn a Husband of the Mode, a fine convenient Tool, one of the Modern humour, a Civil person, that understands Reason, or so; and I doubt not but you wou'd be as Modish a Gallant.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: What, doe you Laugh, Sir?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Who can chuse; to hear your suspicions, your needless Fears. Come, come, trust your Wives discretion, and Modesty— and I doubt not but you will find your self.—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
— In the Rode to Heaven, whither they say all Cuckolds goe— I thank you for your advice; I perceive
you wou'd willingly help me onwards of my Journey.—

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I'm glad I know you, Sir,— farewell to you.—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: No matter for that, so you know not my Wife— and so, farewell to you, Sir, and, the Devil take all Cuckold-makers.

div.stage: SCENE The inside of the House.
Enter Clara, Julia, Antonio, Jacinta running to 'em.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: He has seen Don Carlos, and they have been in great discourse together, I cou'd not hear one word, but you'll have it at both ears anon, I'll warrant you.
Ha, he's coming.—

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Heavens, he must not see you here.—

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Here, step in to Clara's Bed-chamber.—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: So, the Plot's at last discover'd,— he was a Cavalier of his Parole.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Who speak you of?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Onely the Governour, the fine young Governour, I deliver'd him the message, told him my mind, and the like.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: So kind to visit us, and have you sent him away already?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Ah, Witch; already,— why, have I any lodging for him?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: But I am glad you brought him not in, I being so unready.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: But you are always ready for him, my dear victorious Man-slayer.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: What means he, sure he has a Gad-bee in his brain.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Satan's shee Advocate— peace I say;— so,— you look as innocently now, as a little Devil of two years old, I'll warrant;— come, come,— look me full in the face— thus,— turn your nose just to mine— so— now tell me whose damnable Plot this was, to send your Gallant with his Eloquence, Querks and Conundrums, to tutour me into better manners?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Send him; I'll answer no such idle questions.—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
He has taken a world of pains about your particular
Chapter, and no doubt but he preacht according to instructions;— what say you for your self, that Judgment may not pass?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I say, you're an old jealous Fool; have I seen Don Carlos, or heard from Don Carlos, or sent to Don Carlos? here 's a doe indeed.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: What made you at the dore against my positive commands,— the very street dore,— in the night,— alone,— and undrest,— this is matter of Fact, Gentlewoman; you hastned me away,— a plain case,— and presently after Don Carlos comes to the dore,— positive proof,— sees me and falls right down upon my jealousie,— clear conviction,— 'twas pity but I had followed his counsel, yes, when the Devil turns student in Divinity;— but no matter, I'll see your back fairly turn'd upon this Town to morrow; I'll marry my Daughter in the morning to Antonio, and a fair wind or not, we'll home; the Gally lies ready in the Harbour— therefore prepare, pack up your tooles, for you are no woman of this world.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: How? marry me to morrow to his daughter;— and carry his Wife from my friend; this misfortune must be prevented.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: And so, Mistress, come your ways to your Chamber.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: And study how to prevent this cruel separation.
sp.stage: Aside, goes out with him and Jacinta.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Ah Antonio, I find by that sad look of yours, you have over heard our hasty Doom.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: I have, and am a little surpris'd at the suddainness of it; and I my self am the unlucky occasion of it,— to break it off; I told my father how scurvily Isabella treated me,— he thereupon sends for old Francisco, tells him of my complaint, and instead of disingaging my self, I find my self more undone.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: What shall we doe? I'm sure thou wilt not marry her, thou canst not do't and hope to go to Heaven.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: No, I have one prevention left, and if that fail, I'll utterly refuse to marry her, a thing so vainly proud; no Laws of Nature or Religion, sure, can bind me to say yes; and for my Fortune, 'tis my own, no Father can command it.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I know thou wilt be true, and I'll not doubt it.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Ah! Madam, the saddest news—

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Hah! what?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Poor Gentle-man, I pity you of all things in the world,— you must be forc'd— how can I utter it,— to the most lamentable torment that ever Lover endur'd— to remain all night in your Mistress's Chamber.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Alas, how shall I indure so great an affliction?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: And I.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, how I am griev'd to think on't; ha, ha, ha, that you shou'd both be so hardly put to't; ha, ha, ha, for the old Gentle-man has lockt all the dores, and took the keys to bed to him,— go get you in,— ha, ha, ha,—

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Oh, my dear Clara, this is a blessing, I cou'd not hope.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: So large a freedom shall my Vertue prove,
I'll trust my Honour with Antonio's Love.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Don Carlos, in his Night-gown, Antonio and Guzman with Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: ALL night with Clara say'st thou? that was lucky; but was she kind, my friend?

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: As I desir'd, or honour wou'd permit her;
Nor wou'd I press her farther.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: A very moderate Lover.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: For some part of my Vertue, Sir, I owe to you, in midst of all my Love, even in the kindest moments of delight, my joys were broken by concern for you.
— Julia this day, or very suddainly, leaves Cadez.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: By Heaven, and so will Carlos then, for I'm so resolutely bent to possess that dear creature,
sp.l: That I will do't with hazard of my life,
Expence of Fortune, or what's dear to me.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: And how wou'd you reward that politique head, that shou'd contrive the means to bring this hansomly about; not for an hour, or a night, but even as long as you please, with freedom; without the danger of venturing your honourable neck, in showing feats of activitie three stories high, with a Dagger in one hand and a Pistol in t'other, like a Rope-dancer?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: But how? thou talkest of impossibilities.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Dost think she'll e'er consent to quit her Husband?

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: No, Heaven forbid, I am too good a Christian to par: man and wife; but being naturally inclin'd to works of Charity, I will with one project I have in this noddle of mine,— make old Francisco a Cuckold, accommodate my Lord and Julia, serve you, Sir,— and give our selves a good Scene of mirth.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Thou amazests me.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: If I doe't not, send me to the Galleys, nay, and so far cure the jealousie of the old Fellow, that from a rigid suspicious troublesome Fool, he shall become so tame and gentle a Husband,— that he shall desire you to favour him so much as to lie with his dear Wife.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: By what strange Witchcraft shall this be brought to pass?

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: E'n honest invention, Sir, good Faith, listen and believe:—— When he goes, he certainly goes by Sea, to save the charges of Mules.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Right, I heard him say so; in the Galley that lies in the Port.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Good, there is a Galley also, in the Harbour, you lately took from the Turks; habits too were taken in her enough to furnish out some forty or fifty as convenient Turks as a man wou'd wish at the Devil.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Ah Rogue, I begin to apprehend already.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Our Turkish Galley thus man'd, I'll put to Sea, and about a League from Land, with a sham-fight, set on that of old Francisco, take it, make 'em all slaves, clap the old Fellow under hatches, and then you may deal with the fair slave his Wife, as Adam did with Eve.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I'm ravisht with the thought.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: But what will be the event of this?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I will not look so far, but stop at the dear Joys, and Fear no Fate beyond 'em.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Nay, with a little Cudgelling this dull Brain of mine, I shall advance it Farther for the Jest sake;— as I take it, Seignior Don Antonio, you have a fine Villa, within a Bow shot of this City belonging to your self.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: I have, with pleasant Gardens, Grotto's, Water-works.—

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: A most admirable Scene for Love and our designs.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: 'Tis yours, Sir.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Then, Sir, when we have taken this old Fool, on whom the grosest cheat wou'd pass, much more this, which shall carry so seeming a Truth in't, he being clapt under hatches in the Dark, we'll wind round a league or two at Sea, turn in, and Land at this Garden, Sir, of yours, which we'll pretend to be a Seraglio belonging to the Grand Seignior; whither, in this hot part o'th year, he goes to Regale himself with his She Slaves.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: But the Distance of Place and Time allow not such a Falacie.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Why, he never read in's life; knows neither Longitude nor Latitude, and Constantinople may be in the midst of Spain for any thing he knows; besides, his Fear will give him little Leasure for thinking.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: But how shall we doe with the Seamen of this other Gally?

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: There's not above a Dozen, besides the Slaves that are chain'd to the Oar, and those Dozen, a Pistoll a piece wou'd not onely make 'em assist in the Design, but betray it in earnest to the Grand Seignior;— for them I'll undertake, the Master of it being Pier de Sula your Fathers Old Servant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: But possibly his mind may alter upon the Arrival of this false Count of ours?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: No matter, make sure of those Seamen however; that they may be ready upon occasion.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: 'Tis high time for me, that your Count were arriv'd, for this Morning is destin'd the last of my Liberty.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: This Morning— Come haste and dress me—
— Guzman, where's our Count?

div.stage: Enter Guilion drest fine, two great Pages and a little one following.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Coming to give you the good Morrow, Sir. And shew you how well he looks the Part.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Good day to your Lordship—

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Morrow, morrow friend.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: My Lord, your most humble servant.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Thank you friend, thank you; Page, Boy— what'st a Clock Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: About Eight, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Your Lordship's early up?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: My stomach was up before me, friend; and I'm damnable hungry; 'tis strange how a man's Appetite increases with his Greatness; I'll swinge it away now I'm a Lord,— then I will wench without mercy; I'm Resolv'd to spare neither man, Woman, nor Child, not I; hey Rogues, Rascalls, Boys, my Breakfast, quickly Dogs— let me see what shall I have now that's Rare?

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: What will your Honour please to have?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: A small rasher of delicate Bacon, Sirrah— of about a Pound, or two, with a small Morcel of bread— round the Loaf, d'ye hear, quickly Slaves.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: That's grose meat, Sir, a pair of Quails— or—

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: I thank you for that i'faith, take your Don again, an you, please, I'll not be starv'd for nere a Don in Christiandom.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: But you must study to refine your manners a little.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Manners, you shall pardon me for that, as if a Lord had not more privilege to be more sawey, more rude, impertinent, slovenly and foolish than the rest of his Neighbours, or man-kind.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Ay, ay 'tis great.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Your sawey Rudeness, in a Grandee, is Freedom; your Impertinence, Wit; your Sloven, Careless; and your Fool, good Natur'd, at least they shall pass so in me, I'll warrant yee.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Well, you have your full instructions; your Baggage, Bills and Letters, from Octavio the Sivilian Merchant.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: All, all, Sir, are ready, and his Lordship's breakfast waits.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Which ended, we advance,
Just, when Aurora rose from Thetis Bed,
Where he had wanton'd a short Summer's night,
Harnest his bright hoov'd Horses to begin
His Gilded Course about the Firmament,
Out sallyed Don Guilelmo Roderigo de Chimeny swiperio, and so forth. Gad this Adventure of ours will be worthy to be sung in Heroick Rhime Dogerell; before we have finnisht it, Come—

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Hey Rogues, Rascalls, Boys, follow me just behind.

div.head: SCENE II.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Nay I knew he wou'd be Civil, Madam, or I wou'd have born you company, but neither my Mistress nor I, Cou'd sleep one wink all night, for fear of a Discovery in the Morning, and, to save the poor Gentleman a tumbling Cast from the window, my Mistress, just at day break, fain'd her self wondrous sick,— I was call'd, desir'd to goe to Seignior Spadillio's the Apothecary's, at Next door, for a Cordial; and so he slipt out;— but the Story of this False Count pleases me extreamly, and, if it shou'd take, Lord, what mirth we shall have. Ha, ha, ha, I can't forbear with the thoughts on't.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: And to see the Governor his man?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Ah, what a Jest will that be too,— Ha ha ha; but here Comes Isabella; lets puff up her Pride with Flatteries on her Beauty—

div.stage: Enter Isabella looking in a Glass, and setting her Face.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Ah, Heavens, those Eyes,— that Look;— that pretty Lear,— that my Father shou'd be so Doting an old Fool, to think these Beauties fit for a little Merchandize.— a Marchioness wou'd so much better become me.
— ah what a smile's there— and then that scornfull look— tis great— heav'ns who's here?—

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Onely those Friends that wish you better Fortune than this day promises.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Look on that Face; Are there not lines that foretell a world of greatness, and promise much Honour?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Her Face, her Shape, her Mien, her every Part, declares her Lady— or something more.—

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Why so, and yet this little creature of a Father, ridiculous and unambitious, wou'd spoile this Lady, to make up a simple Citizen's Wife— in good time.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: That very look had some presageing Grandure.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Do you think so, Jacinta, Ha, ha, ha.—

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: That laugh again, oh heav'ns, how it Charmes?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Ah how Gracefull 'tis.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Ah, nothing but a great Gilt Coach will become it.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: — With Six Spanish Mares.—

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: — And embroider'd Trapings.—

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: — With four Lackeys.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: — And a Page at the taile on't.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: She's evidently design'd for a Person of quality.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Besides I have so Natural an inclination for a Don, that if my Father do force me to marry this small Creature of a Merchant, I shall make an intreague with some body of quality.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Cou'd you but manage it well and keep it from Antonio.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Keep it from Antonio,— is it think you for a little, silly Cit, to complaine when a Don does him the Honour to Visit his Lady! Marry that were pretty.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: How, a Count, to speak with me; With me, I say,— here at Cadez?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: A Count, Sir, and to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Art sure 'tis not the Governour?— I'll goe lock up my Wife.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Governour, Sir, No, no, 'tis a mear stranger, Sir, a rare Count whom I never saw all dayes of my life before.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: And, with me, wou'd he speak? I hope he comes not to my Wife.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Oh Husband, the delicatest sine Person of Quality, just alighted at the door, Husband.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: What, have you seen him then, the Devil's in these Women, and there be but a loop hole to peep out off they'll spy a man,— I'm resolv'd to see this thing.— goe, retire you women, here's men coming up.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: And will men eat us?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: No, but they may doe worse, they may look on ye, and Looking breeds Likeing; and Likeing, Love; and Love, a damn'd thing, call'd Desire; and Desire begets the Devil and all of Mischief to young wenches.— Get ye gon in, I say,— here's a Lord coming— and Lords are plaguie things to women.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: How, a Lord! oh, heav'ns! Jacinta, my Fan, and set my Hair in order, Oh the Gods! I wou'd not but see a Lord for all the world! how my Heart beats already— keep your Distance behind, Jacinta,— Bless me, how I tremble— a little farther, Jacinta.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Come, come Husewife, you shall be Marry'd anon, and then let your Husband have the Plague of you— but for my Gentlewoman,— Oh Lord— they're here.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: How now, Fellow, where's this old. Don Francisco?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I'm the Person, Sir?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Heav'ns, what an Ayr he has?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Art thou he? Old Lad, how dost thou doe? Hah!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I don't know.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Thou knowest me not it seems, old Fellow, hah!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Know you— no, nor desire to doe,— on what acquaintance pray?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: By Instinct, such as you ought to know a Person of Quality, and pay your Civilities naturally; in France, where I have travell'd, so much good Manners is us'd, your Cittizen puls of his hat, thus— to every Horse of quality, and every Coach of quality; and doe you pay my proper Person, no more respect hah!

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: What a dishonour's this, to me, to have so Dull a Father, that needs to be instructed in his Duty.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: But, Sir, to open the eyes of your understanding— here's a Letter to you, from your Correspondant a Merchant of Sivil.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Cry Mercy, my Lord, and yet I wou'd he were a thousand Leagues off.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: I have bills of Exchange too, directed to thee, old Fellow, at Sivil; but, finding thee not there, and, I (as most persons of my Quality are) being something idle, and never out of my way, came to this Town, to seek thee, Fellow,— being recommended as thou seest here, old Vermin,— here.—

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Ah what a gracefull Mien he has? how sine his conversation? ah, the difference between him and a filthy Citizen.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: — Clara has told me all.—

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: That's she in the middle; stand looking on her languishingly,— your head a little a one side,— so,— fold your arms,— good,— now and then heave your breast with a sigh,— most excellent.—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Bills for many many thousands.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: He has you in his eye already.—

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Ah, Jacinta thou flatterest me.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Return him some kind looks in pity.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: That other's my Mistress,— cou'd'st thou but keep this old Fellow in discourse whilst I give her the sign to retire a little.—

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: I'll warrant you I'll banter him till you have Cuckold him, If you manage matters as well as I.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
My Lord, I ask your pardon for my rudeness in not knowing you before, which I ought to have done in good manners, I confess;— who the Devil does he stare at so?— Wise, I command you to withdraw, upon pain of our high displeasure.— my Lord, I shall dispatch your affairs,— he minds me not,— Ay,— 'tis my Wife,— I say, Minion, begon,— your Bills, my Lord, are good, and I accept Julia goes to t'other side to Carlos. em;— why, what a Devil he minds me not yet,— and though I am not at my proper home— I am where I can command Money,— hum,— sure 'tis my daughter,— Ay, ay,— 'tis so, how if he shou'd be smitten
now; the plaguie jade had sure the spirit of Prophesie in her; 'tis so,— 'tis she,— my Lord.—

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Prethee, old Fellow, peace,— I am in Love.—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: In Love,— what, shall I be the Father of a Lord, wou'd it become me, think ye?— he's mighty full of Cogitabund;— my Lord,— my Lord,— sure his Soul has left the Tenement of his Body,— I have his Bills here, and care not if it never return more.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Dear Julia, let's retire, our time's but short.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I dare not with you, the venture wou'd be too bold in a young beginner in the Thefts of Love.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: — Her Eyes are Suns, by Jove.—

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Oh, nothing is so ventrous as Love, if it be true.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.l: — Or else, two Morning Stars,
All other Beauties are but Soot to her.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: But shou'd my husband—

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: He's safe for one dear half hour, I'll warrant you, come.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Um— my Wife here still,— must I begin to thunder?—

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Lord, and you be so froward, I'll be gone.—

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: So, her Husband kind heart lest she should be cruel, has himself given me the dear opportunity.—
— Be sure you keep the old Fellow in discourse a while.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Be you as sure to Cuckold him.—
— Old Fellow,— prethee what person of quality's that?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Person of quality,— alas, my Lord, 'tis a silly Citizen's daughter.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: A Citizen's; what clod of earth cou'd bring forth such a Beauty?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Alas, my Lord, I am that clod of Earth, and to Earth if you call it so, she must return again, for she's to be married to a Citizen this Morning.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Oh! I am doubly wounded, first with her harmonious eyes,
sp.l: Who've sir'd my heart to that degree,
No Chimney ever burnt like me.
sp.p: Fair Lady,— suffer the Broom of my Affection to sweep all other Lovers from your heart.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Ah, my Lord, name it not, I'm this day to be married.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p:
To day;— name me the Man, Man, did I say, the Monster that dares lay claim to her, I dain to love,— none
answer me,— I'll make him smoak by Vulcan— and all the rest of the Goddesses.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Bless me, what a furious thing this Love is?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: By this bright sword, that is so us'd to slaughter, he dies; old Fellow, say— the Poltroons name.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Oh fearful— alas, dread Sir!—

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Ah! sheath your Sword, and calm your generous Rage.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: I cannot brook a Rival in my Love, the rustling Pole of my affection is too strong to be resisted.—
sp.stage: Runs raging up and down the Stage with his Sword in his hand.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I cannot think, my Lord, so mean a Beauty, can so suddenly charm a heart so great as yours.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Oh! you're mistaken, as soon as I cast my eyes upon the full moon of your countenance, I was struck blind and dumb.—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Ay, and deaf too, I'll be sworn, he cou'd neither hear, see nor understand; this Love's a miraculous thing.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: And that minute, the most renoun'd Don Guilelmo Roderigo de Chimeny-swiperio, became your Galley slave,— I say no more, but that I do Love,— and I will Love, and that if you are but half so willing as I, I will dub you, Vicountess de Chimeny Swiperio.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: I am in Heaven, ah! I dye, Jacinta.
How can I credit this, that am so much unworthy?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: I'll doe't, say no more, I'll doe't.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Doe't, but my Lord, how, and with what face can I put off Signior Antonio, hum?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Antonio,— hay, Pages, give order that Antonio be instantly run through the Lunges— d'ye hear?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Oh, hold, hold, my Lord! run through the Lunges.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: It shall be done, my Lord, but, what Antonio?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Why any Antonio; all the Antonio's that you find in 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Oh, what bloody minded Monsters these Lords are!— But, my Lord, I'll ne'r give you the trouble of killing him, I'll put him off with a handsome compliment; as thus,— Why, look ye, Friend Antonio, the business is this, my Daughter Isabella may marry a Lord, and you may go fiddle.—

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p:
Ay, that's civil,— and if he do not desist, I'll unpeople Spain but I'll kill him; for, Madam, I'll tell you what happened to me in the Court of France— there was a Lady in
the Court in love with me,— she took a liking to my Person which,— I think,— you will confess.—

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: To be the most accomplisht in the World.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: — I had some sixscore Rivals, they all took snuff; that is, were angry,— at which I smil'd;— they were incensed, at which I laught, ha, ha, ha,— i'faith; they rag'd, I— when I met '●…m,— Cockt, thus— en passant— justled 'em— thus,—
They turn'd and frown'd,— thus,— I— drew.—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: What, on all the sixscore, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: All, all; sa sa, quoth I, sa sa sa, sa sa sa.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Hold, hold, my Lord, I am none of the sixscore.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: — and run 'em all through the body—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Oh Heavens! and kild 'em all.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Not a man,— onely run 'em through the Body a little, that's all; my two boys were by, my Pages here.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Is it the fashion, Sir, to be attended by Pages so big?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Pages of honour always;— these were stinted at nurse, or they had been good proper fellows.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I am so frighted with this relation, that I must up to my Wifes Chamber for a little of that stong Cordial that recover'd her this morning.—

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Why, I'll tell you, Sir, what an odd sort of a wound I received in a duel the other day,— nay, Ladies, I'll show it you; in a very odd place— in my back parts.
sp.stage: Goes to untuck his breeches, the Ladies squeak.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Ah!

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: Show a wound behind, Sir, the Ladies will think you are a Coward.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Peace Child, peace, the Ladies understand Dueling as little as my self;— but, since you are so tender-hearted, Ladies, I'll not show my wound; but faith, it spoil'd my dancing.

sp.speaker: Page,
sp.p: My Lord, now you talk of dancing, here's your baggage brought from a-board the Gally by your Sea-men, who us'd to entertain you with their rustick sports.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p:
Very well; Sir, with your permission, I am resolv'd whether you will, or no, to give the Ladies some divertisement,
— bid 'em come in; nay, Sir, you stirr not,

'Tis for your delight, Sir, I doe't; for, Sir, you must understand, a man, if he have any thing in him, Sir, of Honour, for the case, Sir, lies thus, 'tis not the business of an Army to droll upon an Enemy,— truth is, every man loves a whole skin;— but, 'twas the fault of the best States-man in Christendome to be loose in the hilts;— you conceive me.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Very well, my Lord, I'll swear he's a rare spoken man;— why, what a Son-in-law shall I have? I have a little business my Lord, but I'll wait on you presently.

sp.speaker: Guil.
