sp.p: — Sir, there is nothing like your true Jest, a thing once well done, is twice done, and I am the happiest man in the World in your alliance;— for, Sir, a Noble-man if he have any tollerable parts,— is a thing above the Vulgar;— oh,— here come the Dancers;
Come, sit down by me.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: 'Tis my duty to stand, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Nay, you shall sit.—

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Good day, Sir, I hope you will not chide my tardiness, I have a little overslept my self, and am asham'd to see my lovely Bride, and all this worthy company attend;— But you, fair Creature.—

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: No marrying to day, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: No, Sir, no marrying to day.—

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: How, do I dream, or hear this from Francisco?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: How now, Fellow, what art thou?

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: The Husband of that proud disdainfull Woman.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Another word like that,— and thou art—

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: — What, Sir?—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: — Oh, hold, hold, my Lord! Antonio, I must tell you, you're uncivil.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.l: Dost know, dull Mortal, that I am a Lord,
And Isabella my adopted Lady?

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, Sir, if it be so, poor Mortals can but grieve in silence.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Alas poor Mortal!

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: But, for you, Francisco.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Ah, dear Antonio, I vow and swear I cannot chuse but weep to lose thee; but my Daughter was born for a Lady and none can help their destinie.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: And is it possible thou canst use me thus?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Take away that little Fellow, in pity of your life, I dain to bid you withdraw and be safe.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: D'ye hear, hah?— this Lady has beg'd your life.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Beg'd my life.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Vile wretch, darest thou retort?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Oh! hold, hold my noble son-in-law, he shall doe any thing;— dear Antonio, consider,— I was never Father to a Lord all daies of my life before:— my Lord, be pacified, my Daughter shall be a Lady.—

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: For my sake, spare him, and be Friends with him, as far as you may dain to be with a little Citizen.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Fellow, I forgive thee,— here's my hand to kiss in sign and token I am appeas'd
sp.stage: [Gives him his hand to kiss, 'tis all black.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: A Pox of his honourable hand, 't had like to have spoil'd all,— well,— since it must be so,— I am content—

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: So, now peace is concluded on, on all sides, what shall we do to day besides eating and drinking in abundance; for to morrow I shall get my self in order for my marriage?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: What thinks your Honour of taking the air upon the Sea, in a Gally, a League or two?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: With Fiddles, Drums and Trumpets, West-Phalia hams and Pigeons and the like: Hey Rogues, Scoundrels, Dogs.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Ah, how fine is every action of a great man!

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.l: Command a Gally to attend us presently,
— you shall along, old Boy.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Alas, I must stay at home with my Wife, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: A Wife! have I a Mother-in-law too?— she must along with us, and take a frisk,— no denial:
— Oh, are you come?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Yes and thank thee for the best moment of my life:— hast thou contriv'd the Voyage then?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Take no care— come haste on board— our honour will not lose the Fresco of the morning,— Follow me— Pages.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: At your heels, my Lord,—

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter, as a board the Ship, Guilion, Isabella, Francisco, Julia, Antonio, Clara, Jacinta, Pedro and his Wife, Pages.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: LAdyes and Gentlemen, you are wellcome aboard,— Come, put off to sea, Rogues, Scoundrells, Tarpaulins, to your business, and then, every man his Bottle,— hey Page, Rogues, where are my men? Come, spread the Table— for we are very hungry.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Heav'ns, what a peculiar Grace there is in every word that comes from the Mouth of a Cavalier!

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: By Mars, the God of Love!

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: By Cupid, Sir.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Cupid, Sirrah, I say, I'll have it Mars, there's more Thunder in the sound! I say, by Mars, these Gallies are pretty neat convenient Teniments— but a— I see ne'r a Chimney in 'em;— Pox on't, what have I to doe with a Chimney now?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: He is a delicate, fine person, Jacinta, but, methinks, he does not make Love enough to me.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, Persons of his Quality never make Love in words, the greatness of their Actions show their Passion.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Ay, tis true all the little Fellows talk of love.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Come, Ladyes, set; Come Isabella, you are Melancholy,— Page— Fill my Lady a Beer-glass.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Ah, Heav'ns, a Beer-glass.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p:
O your Vicountess never drinks under your Beer-glass, your Citizens Wives simper and sip, and will be drunk without doing Credit to the Treater; but in their Closets, they
swinge it away, whole Slashes i'faith, and egad, when a woman drinks by her self, Glasses Come thick about? your Gentle woman, or your little Lady, drinks half way, and thinks in point of good manners, she must leave some at the bottom, but your true-bred Woman of Honour drinks all, Supernaculum, by Jove.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: What a misfortune it was, that I shou'd not know this before, but shou'd discover my want of so necessary a piece of grandure.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: And nothing, but being Fudled, will redeem her Credit.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Come— fall to, old Boy,— thou art not merry; what have we none that can give us a song?

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, we have an Artist aboard I'll assure you; Seignior Cashier, shall I beg the favour of you to show your Skill?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Sir, my Wife and I'm at your service.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Friend, what Language can you Sing?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, your Singers speak all Languages.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Sayst thou so, prethee then let's have a touch of Heathen Greek.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: That you shall, Sir, Sol la me fa sol, &c.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Hum, I think this is indeed Heathen Greek. I'm sure tis so to me.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Ay, that may be, but I understand every word on't.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Good lack, these Lords are very Learned men.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Now, Sir, you shall hear one of an other Language from my Wife and I.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Well Gentlemen though the news be somthing unpleasant that I bring, yet to Noble minds 'tis sport and pastime.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Hah Fellow! Whats that thats sport and pastime to Noble minds?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Oh Lord, no goodness I'll warrant.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: But, Gentlemen, pluck up your spirits, be bold and resolute.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Oh Lord, bold and resolute, why what's the matter, Captain?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: You are old, Seignior, and we expect no good from you but prayers to Heav'n?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Oh Lord, Prayers to Heav'n! Why I hope, Captain, we have no need to think of Heav'n.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: At your own Peril be it then, Seignior, for the Turks are coming upon us.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Oh Lord, Turks, Turks!

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Turks, oh, is that all?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: All— why they'll make Eunuchs of us, my Lord, Eunuchs of us poor men, and ly with all our Wives!

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Shaw, that's nothing, 'tis good for the Voice,— how sweetly we shall sing, ta, la, ta la la, ta la, &c.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Ay, 'twill make you sing another note, I ll warrant you.

sp.speaker: Sea.
sp.p: For Heav'ns sake, Sirs, doe not stand Idle here; Gentlemen, if you wou'd save your lives,— draw, and defend 'em.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Draw, I never drew any thing in my life, but my Purse, and that most damnably against my will; oh, what shall I doe?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Ah, my Lord, they bear up briskly to us, with a Fresh Gale and full Sails.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Oh, dear Captain, let's tack-about and goe home again.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: 'Tis impossible to scape, we must fight it out.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Fight it out, oh I'm not able to indure it,— why, what the Devil made me a ship-board?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Why, where be these Turks! Set me to 'em, I'll make 'em smoke, dogs, to dare attack a man of Quality.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Oh, the insolence of these Turks? do they know who's Aboard? For Heav'ns sake, my Lord, do not expose your Noble Person.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: What, not fight!— Not fight! A Lord, and not fight? Shall I submit to Fetters, and see my Mistress ravisht by any great Turk in Christiandom, and not fight?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I'd rather be ravisht a thousand times, then you shou'd Venture your Person.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Ay I dare swear.

sp.speaker: Sea.
sp.p: Ah, Sirs, what mean you, come on the Deck for shame.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: My Lord, let us not tamely fall, there's danger near.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Ay, Ay, there's never smoake but there's some fire— come let's away— ta la, tan ta la, la la, &c.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: A Pox of all Lords, I say, you must be Janting in Devil's-name, and Gods dry Ground wou'd not serve your 〈◊〉,
Oh how they Thunder! What shall I do— oh for some Auger hole to thrust my Head into, for I could never indure the Noise of Cannons,— oh 'tis insupportable,— intollerable and not to be indur'd.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Dear Father, be not so frighted!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Ah, Crocodile, wou'd thou hadst wept thy Eyes out long agoe that thou hadst never seen this Count; then he had never lovd thee, and then we had never been invited a ship-board.

div.stage: Enter Guilion, Pet. and Antonio. Driven in fighting by Guzman and other Turks.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Ah, Sir, the Turks have boarded us, we re lost we re lost

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Oh, I am slain, I'm slain.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Hold,— hold, I say, you are now in the presence of Ladies, and 'tis uncivil to fight before Ladies.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Yield then, you are our slaves.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Slaves, no Sir, we're slaves to none but the Ladies.—

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Oh, hold, rude man— D'ye know whom you encounter?

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: What's here— one dead—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Oh, Lord!

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Or, if he be not, he's old, and past service, we'll kill the Christian Dog out of the way.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Oh, hold, hold, I'm no Christian, Gentlemen; but as errant a Heathen as your selves.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Bind him Streight neck and heels, and Clap him under Hatches.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Oh, spare him, Sir, look on his Reverend Age.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: For your sake, Lady, much may be done, we've need of handsom women.
sp.stage: [Gives her to some Turks that are by.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Hah,— my Wife! My Wife Ravisht— oh I'm dead.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Fear not, my Dear, I'll rather dye than doe thee wrong.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Wou'd she wou'd, quickly,— then there's her honour sav'd, and her ransome, which is better.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Down with the muttering Dog.
— And take the Ladies to several Cabins.
sp.stage: [The Turks take hold of the Men

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Must we be parted then,— ah, cruel Destinie!

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Alas! this separation's worse than death.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: You possibly may see some Turkish Ladies, that may insnare your heart, and make you faithless;— but I, ah Heavens! if ever I change my Love, may I become deform'd, and lose all hopes of Title or of Grandure.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: But thou'd the Grand Signior behold thy Beauty, thou wou'dst dispise thine own dear hony Vicount to be a Sultana.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: A Sultana, what's that?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Why, 'tis a she great Turk; a Queen of Turkey.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: These dear expressions go to my heart.—
And yet a Sultana is a tempting thing—
— And you shall find your Isabella true,— though the Grand Signior wou'd lay his Crown at my feet,— wou'd he wou'd try me though,— Heavens! to be Queen of Turkey.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: May I believe thee,— but when thou seest the difference, alas, I am but a Chimney— hum, nothing to a great Turk.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Is he so rare a thing— oh that I were a the Great Turk.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Come, come, we can't attend your Amorous 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Alas, and what shall we poor women doe?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: We must e'en have patience, Madam, and be ravisht.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Ravisht! Heavens forbid.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: An please the Lord, I'll let my nails grow against 〈◊〉 direfull day.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: And so will I, for I'm resolv'd none shall ravish me but the Great Turk.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Come, Ladies, you are Dishes to be serv'd up to the board of the Grand Signior.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Why, will he eat us all?

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: A slice of each, perhaps, as he finds his appetite 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: A slice, uncivil Fellow,— as if this Beauty were for a bit and away;— Sir, a word,— if you will do me the favour to recommend me to be first serv'd up to the Grand Signior, I shall remember the civility when I am great.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Lady, he is his own Carver, a good word by the by, or so, will doe well, and I am,— a Favorite—

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Are you so, here, take this Jewel,— in earnest of greater Favours—

div.head: SCENE II. A Garden.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: But, why so near the Land? by Heaven I saw each action 〈◊〉 the Fight, from yonder grove of Jesemine, And doubtless all beheld it from the Town.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: The Captain, Sir, design'd it so, and at the Harbour gave it out those two Galleys were purposely prepar'd to entertain the Count and the Ladies with the representation of a Sea-fight: lest the noise of the Guns should Alarm the Town, and, taking 〈◊〉 for a real Fight, shoud have sent out supplies, and so have ●…in'd our designs.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Well, have we all things in readiness?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: All, Sir, all.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: My Lord, a Barge from the Gally is just arriv'd at the Garden Stairs.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I'll retire then, and fit me for my part of this Farce.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: My Lord, you must retire, they're just bringing the old Gentleman a shore.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Prethee how does he take his Captivity?

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Take it, Sir, he has cast himself into a fit, and has lain like one in a Trance this half hour; tis impossible for him to speak Sense this fortnight; Ill secure his Reason a play-day for so long at least; your servants, in Turkish habits, are now his 〈◊〉, who will keep him safe enough from hindering your delights with 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What ever you doe have a care you do not overfright the Coxcomb, and make a Tragedy of our Comedy.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: I'll warrant you, Sir, mind you your Love affairs;— he's coming in,— retire, Sir.—

div.stage: Enter some Turks with the Body of Francisco in Chains, and lay him down on a Bank.

sp.speaker: 1 Tu.
sp.p: Christian, so ho ho, Slave awake.—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: — Hah!— where am I?— my Wife,— my Wife,— where am I?— hah!— what are you?— Ghosts,— Devils,— Mutes,— no answer,— hah,— bound in chains,— Slaves, where am I?

sp.speaker: 1 Tu.
sp.p: They understand not your Language, but I, who am a Renigado Spaniard, understand you when you speak civily, which I advise you to doe.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Do you know me, Friend?

sp.speaker: 1 Tu.
sp.p: I know you to be a Slave, and the Great Turk's Slave too.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: The Great Turk,— the Great Devil, why where am I, Friend?

sp.speaker: 1 Tu.
sp.p: Within the Territories of the Grand Signior, and this, a Palace of Pleasure, where he recreates himself with his Mistresses.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: And how far is that from Cadez;— but what care I, my Wife, Friend, my own Wife.

sp.speaker: 1 Tu.
sp.p: Your own,— a true Musselman cou'd have said no more; but take no care for her, she s provided for.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Is she dead, that would be some comfort,—

sp.speaker: 1 Tu.
sp.p: No, she's alive and in good hands.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: And in good hands; oh, my head! and, oh, my heart! ten thousand tempests burst the belly of this day wherein old Francisco ventur'd Life and Limb,— Liberty and Wife to the mercy of these Heathen Turks.

sp.speaker: 1 Tu.
sp.p: Friend, you need not thus complain;— a good round ransom redeems ye.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: A round ransom, I'll rot in my chains first, before I 'll part with a round ransom.

sp.speaker: 1 Tu.
sp.p: You have a fair Wife, and need not fear good usage if she knows how to be kind;— you apprehend me.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Patience, good Lord.

sp.speaker: 1 Tu.
sp.p: Perhaps the Grand Signior may like her, and to be favour'd by him is such a Glory.—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: As the Devil take me if I desire.—

sp.speaker: 1 Tu.
sp.p: — And then you may in triumph laugh at all the rest of your Brother Cuckolds.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Hum,— and has the Devil serv'd me thus,— but no matter, I must be gadding, like an old Coxcombe, to Cad●…,— and then, jan●…ing to Sea, with a Pox, to take pains to be a Cuckold,— to bring my Wife into a strange Land, amongst Unbelievers, with a vengeance, as if we had not honest Christian Cuckold-makers enough at home; Sot that I was, not to consider how many Merchants have been undone by trusting their Commodities out at Sea;— why, what a damn'd ransom will the Rogues exact from me, and more for my Wife because she's hansome, and then, 'tis ten to one, I have her turn d upon my hands the worse for wearing; oh, damn'd Infidels!— no, tis resolv'd, I'll live a slave here, rather than enrich them.

sp.speaker: 1 Tu.
sp.p: Friend, you'll know your destiny presantly;— for, tis the custom of the Great Turk to view the Captives, and consider of their ransoms and liberties according to his pleasure,— see he is coming forth with the Vizer Bassa;
sp.stage: Enter Carlos and Guzman as Turks with followers.
sp.p: Most mighty Emperour, behold your Captive.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Is this the Great Turk?

sp.speaker: 1 Tu.
sp.p: Peace.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Bless me! as we at home describe him, I thought the Great Turk had been twice as big, but, I shall find him Tyrant big enough, I'll warrant him.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Of what Nation art thou, Slave, speak to the Emperour he understands thee, though he deign not to hold discourse to Christians, Dogs.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Oh fearfull!— Spain so please you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: By Mahomet, he'll make a reverend Eunuch.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: An Eunuch,— oh, Lord!—

sp.speaker: 1 Tu.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, to guard his Mistresses, 'tis an honour.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
Oh! Mercy,— Sir, that honour you may spare,
Age has done my business as well already.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Fellow what art?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: An't please your worship, I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: How, not tell?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: An't please your Lordship, my Fears have so transform'd me, I cannot tell whether I'm any thing or nothing.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Thy Name, Dull mortall, know'st thou not that?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: An't please your Grace, now I remember me, methinks I doe.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Dog, how art thou Call'd?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: An't like your Excellence, men Call'd me Seignior Don Francisco but now they will call me Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Of what Trade?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: An't please your Highness, a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: How much dost thou get a day by that Trade?— Hah!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: An't like your Majesty, our Gentlemen never get but twice in all their Lives; that is, when Fathers dy, they get good Estates; and when they Marry, they get rich Wives; but I know what your Mightyness wou'd get by going into my Country and asking the Question.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: What, Fool?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: A good Cudgelling, an't please your Illustriousness.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Slave! To my Face!— Take him away and let him have the Strapado.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Baridama, 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Heav'ns, what sayes he?

sp.speaker: 1 Tu.
sp.p: He means to have you castriated.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Castriated! Oh that s some dreadfull thing I'll warrant— Gracious Great Turk, for Mahomet's sake, excuse me; alas, I've lost my wits.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Galero Gardines?

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: The Emperor asks it thou art Married, Fellow.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Hah— Married— I was ant like your Monsterousness, but, I doubt your people have spoyl'd my Property.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: His Wise, with other Ladies, in a Pavillion in the Garden, attend your Royall pleasure.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Go, setch her hither presently—

sp.speaker: 1 Tu.
sp.p: This is no common honour, that the Great Turk degns to speak your Language; tis a sign you ll 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Yes, by the height of a pair of Horns.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Is she hansom?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Oh, what an Ague shakes my heart,— hansom, aha, no, dread Sir; what shou'd such a deform'd Poulcat as I do with a hansom Wife?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Is she young?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Young— what shou'd such an old doting Coxcomb as I do with a young-Wife— Pox on him for a Heathen Whore master.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Old is she then?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Ay, very old, an't please your Gloriousness.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Is she not Capable of Love?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Hum,— so so, like sire conceald in a Tinder-box,— I shall run Mad.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Is she witty?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I'm no Competent Judge, an't like your Holyness,— this Catechism was certainly of the Devil's own making.

div.stage: Enter Guzman, bringing in Julia, Clara, Isabella, Jacinta, Guilion, Antonio: &c. Women vail'd.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: These, Sir, are all the Slaves of Note are taken.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Dost think, Jacinta, he'll chuse me?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I'll warrant you, Madam, if he look with my Eyes.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Stand forth—

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Stand sorth, Sir, why, so I can, Sir: I dare show my Face, Sir, before any Great Turk in Christiandom.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What are you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: What am I, Sir? Why, I'm a Lord, a Lord.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Are you mad to own your quality, he'll ask the Devil an all of a ransom.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: No matter for that, I'll not lose an Inch of my Quality for a King's Ransom, disgrace my self before my fair Mistress.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: That's as the Great Turk and I shall agree.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What are you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: A Citizen of Cadez.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Set 'em by, we'll Consider of their Ransoms— now unvaile the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
Oh, dear Wife, now or never show thy Love, make a
Damnable face upon the silthy Ravisher,— glout thy Eyes thus— and thrust out thy upper lip, thus—

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Oh, dear Isabella, do thee look like a Dog too.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: No, Sir, I'm resolv'd I'll not loose an Inch of my Beauty, to save so trifling a thing as a Maiden head.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Very agreeable, pretty and Chearfull— a most divine Bud of Beauty— all natures Excellence— drawn to the life in Little,— what are you, fair one?

div.stage: She is Veild and set by: Then Cla ra is unveild.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Sir, I'm a Maid.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: So, I hope, he will pitch upon her.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Onely, by promise, Sir, I've given my self away.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What happy man cou'd claim a title in thee, And trust thee to such danger?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Heav'ns, shall I be defeated by this little Creature! What pity 'twas he saw not me first?

sp.speaker: Cla
sp.p: I dare not name him, Sir, least this small Beauty which you say adornes me, shou'd gain him your displeasure; he's in your Presence, Sir, and is your slave.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Such innocence this plain Confession shows, Name me the man, and I'll resign thee back to him.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: A Pox of his Civility.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: This mercy makes me bold to claim my right.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Take her, Young man, and with it both your Ransoms.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Hum— hum— very noble i'faith, we'll e'en confess our loves too, Isabella.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Slife he'l spoil all,— hold— pray let your betters be serv'd before you.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: How! Is the Honour of my Love despised?— wer't not i'th presence of the Great Turk, for whom I have a reverence because he's a man of quality— by Jove I'd draw upon you.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Because you were my Lover once, when I am Queen I'll Pardon you;—

div.stage: Guzman unveils her, and leads her to Carlos, she making ridiculous Actions of Civility.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What Akward— fond— Conceited Thing art thou? Veile her and take the Taudry Creature hence.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Hum— your Majesty's humble servant—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: How! refuse my Daughter too; I see the Lot of a Cuckold will fall to my share.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: This is the Wife, Great Sir, of this old Slave.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Hah! what do I see, by Mahomet, she's fair.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: So, so, she's condemn'd, oh, damn'd Mahometan Canibal! will nothing but raw flesh serve his turn?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I'll see no more,— here I have fix'd my heart.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Oh, Monster of a Grand Signior!

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Have you a mind to be flead, Sir?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Receive my Handkerchief.—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: His Handkerchief; bless me what does he mean?

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: To doe her the honour to lie with her to night.—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Oh, hold, most mighty Turk.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Slave, darest thou interrupt 'em,— dye, Dog.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Hold, hold, I'm silent.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I Love you fair one, and design to make you—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: A most notorious Strumpet,— a Pox of his courtesie.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: — What Eyes you have like Heaven-blew and charming, a pretty Mouth, Neck, round and white as polisht Alabaster, and a complexion, beauteous as an Angel,— a ha●… fit to make Bonds to insnare the God of Love,— a sprightly Air,— a hand like Lillies white, and Lips, no Roses opening in a Morning are half so sweet and soft.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Oh, damn'd circumcifed Turk.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: You shall be call'd the bautifull Sultana,
And rule in my Seraglio drest with jewels.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Sure I shall burst with vengeance.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Sir, let your Vertue regulate your passions; For I can ne'r love any but my husband.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Ah, dis mbling Witch!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: — And wou'd not break my marriage Vows to him, for all the honour you can heap upon me.

Say, and hold; but, Sultana and pretious Stones, are damnable temptations,— besides, the Rogue's young and hansome,— What a scornfull look she casts at me; wou'd they 〈◊〉 both hansomly at the Devil together.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Dog,— do you mutter?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Oh! nothing, nothing, but the Palsey shook my Lip a little.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Slave, go, and, on your knees, resign your Wife.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
she 's of years of discretion,— and may dispose of her self
self; but I can hold no longer,— and, is this your Mahometan Conscience, to take other mens Wives, as if there were not single Harlots enough in the world?

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Peace, thou diminutive Christian.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I say, peace, thou over-grown Turk,

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Thou Spanish Cur.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Why, you're a Mahometan Bitch, and you go to that.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Death, I'll dissect the bald pated Slave.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I defie thee, thou foul filthy Cabbage head, for I am mad, and will be valiant.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What Insolence is this?— Mutes— strangle him.—
sp.stage: [They put a Bow-string about his neck.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Mercy, dread Sir, I beg my Husband's life.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: No more,— this fair one bids you live,— hence forth, Francisco, I pronounce you a Widower, and shall regard you, for the time to come, as the deceased Husband of the Great Sultana, murmer not upon pain of being made an Eunuch— take him away—

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Go, and be satisfied, I'll die before I'll vield.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Is this my going to Sea?— the Plague of losing Battels light on thee.
sp.l: When ill success shall make thee idle lie,
Mayst thou in bed be impotent as I.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Command our Slaves to give us some diversion; Dismiss his Chains, and use him with respect, because he was the Husband of our beloved Sultana.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I see, your Cuckold might have a life good enough if he cou'd be contented—
sp.stage: [Carlos and Julia sit under an Vmbrello.

lg.l: How strangely does my Passion grow,
Divided equally 'twixt two?
Damon had ne'er subdu'd my Heart,
Had not Alexis took his part:
Nor, cou'd Alexis powerfull prove,
Without my Damon's aid, to gain my Love.
When my Alexis present is,
Then I for Damon sigh and mourn;
But, when Alexis I do miss,
Damon gains nothing but my scorn:
And, if it chance they both are by;
For both, alas! I languish, sigh, and die.
Cure then, thou mighty Winged God,
This raging Feaver in my Blood.
One golden-pointed Dart take back;
But, which, O Cupid, wilt thou take?
If Damon's, all my hopes are crost:
Or, that of my Alexis, I am lost.

div.stage: Enter Dancers, which dance an Antique

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Come, my dear Julia, let's retire to Shades. [Aside to her.
Where onely thou and I can find an enterance;
These dull, these necessary delays of ours
Have drawn my Love to an impatient height,
— attend these Captives,— at a respectfull distance.
sp.stage: [Ex. all but Isa. who staies Guil.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: What wou'd the Great Sultana?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Ah! do not pierce my heart with this unkindness.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha,— Pages,— give order, I have Letters writ to Sivil, to my Merchant,— I will be ransom'd instantly.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Ah, cruel Count!

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Meaning me, Lady; ah, fie! no, I am a Scoundrel; I a Count, no, not I, a Dog, a very Chim— hum,— a son of a Whore, I, not worthy your notice.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Oh, Heavens! must I lose you then? no, I'll die first.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Die, die, then, for, your betters must be serv'd before you.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Oh! I shall rave; false and lovely, as you are, did you not swear to marry me, and make me a Vicountess.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Ay, that was once when I was a Lover, but, now you are a Queen,— you're too high i'th' mouth for me.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Ah! name it not; will you be still hard-hearted?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: As a Flint, by Jove.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Have you forgot your Love?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: I've a bad memory.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: And will you let me die?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: I know nothing of the matter.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Oh, Heavens! and shall I be no Vicountess?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Not, for me, Fair Lady, by Jupiter,— no, no,— Queen's much better,— Death, affront a man of Honour, a Vicount that wou'd have took you to his Bed,— after half the Town had blown upon you,— without examining either Portion or Honesty, and wou'd have took you for better for worse— Death, I'll untile houses, and demolish Chimneys, But I'll be reveng'd.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Ah, hold! your anger's just, I must confess, yet pardon the frailty of my Sexes vanity; behold my tears, that sue for pity to you.
sp.stage: [She weeps, he stands looking on her.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: — My Rage dissolves.—

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I ask but death or pity.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: — I cannot hold,— but, if I shou'd forgive, and marry you, you wou'd be gadding after honour still, longing to be a she Great Turk again.—

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Break not my heart with such suspicions of me.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: And, is it pure and tender Love for my Person, And not for my glorious Titles?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Name not your Titles, 'tis your self I love,
Your amiable, sweet and charming self,
And, I cou'd almost wish you were not great,
To let you see my Love.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.l: I am confirm'd—
'Tis no respect of Honour makes her weep;
Her Love's the same shou'd I crie— Chimney Sweep.

div.head: SCENE I. A Garden.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: NOW am I afraid to walk in this Garden, lest I shou'd spie my own natural Wife lying with the Great Turk in Fresco upon some of these fine flowry Banks, and learning how to make Cuckolds in Turkey.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Nay, dear Jacinta, cast an eye of pity on me. What, deny the Vizer Bassa.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: When you are honest Guzman again, I'll tell you a piece of my mind.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: But, opportunity will not be so kind to Guzman, as to the Grand Bassa; therefore, dear Rogue, let's retire into these kind shades, or, if foolish Vertue be so squeamish, and needless Reputation so nice, that Mr. Vicar must say Amen to the bargain, there is an old lousey Fryer, belonging to this Villa, that will give us a cast of his office, for I am a little impatient about this business, Greatness, having infus'd a certain itch in my blood, which I felt not, whilst a common man.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Um, Why, what have we here, pert Mrs. Jacinta, and the Bassa? I hope the Jade will be Turkeyfied with a vengeance, and have Circumcision in abundance; and the Devil shall ransom her for old Francisco.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Hah, the old Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: What? the Frolick is to go round, I see, you women have a happy time on't.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Men that have kind Wives may be as happy; you'll have the honour of being made a Cuckold, Heaven be prais'd.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, I thank ye,— pray under the Rose, how 〈◊〉 my Wife please his Grace the Great Turk?

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Murmuring again, thou Slave.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Who, I? O Lord, Sir! no, not I, why, what hurt is there in being a Cuckold?

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Hurt, Sirrah, you shall be swing'd into a belief, that it is an honour for the Great Turk to borrow your wife.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: But, for the Lender to pay Use-money, is somewhat severe;— but, see, he comes,— bless me, how grim he looks!

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Come hither, Slave,— why was it that I gave you Life dismist the fetters from your aged limbs?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: For love of my Wife, and t please your Barbarousness.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: — Gave you free leave to range the Palace round, excepting my apartment onely?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Still, for my Wives sake, I say, and t'like your Hideousness.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: And yet, this Wife, this most ungratefull Wife of yours again wou'd put your chains on, expose your life to dangers and new torments by a too stubborn vertue, she does refuse my courtship, and foolish is chast.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Alas! what pity's that?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I offer'd much, lov'd much, but all in vain;
Husband, and Honour, still, was the reply.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Good lack! that she shou'd have no more Grace before her eyes.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: But, Slave, behold these Mutes; that fatal instrument of death behold too, and in 'em read thy doom, if this coy Wife of yours be not made flexible to my addresses.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Oh, Heavens! I make her.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: No more, thy Fate is fix'd— and, here attend, till he himself deliver his willing Wife into my arms: Bassa, attend and see it, see it be perform'd—

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Go, one of you, and fetch the fair slave hither.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I Pimp for my own Wife, I hold the dore to my own Flesh and Blood, O monstrum horrendum!

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Nay, doe't, and doe't hansomly too, not with a snivelling countenance, as if you were compell'd to't;— but, with the face of authority, and the awfull command of a Husband— or— thou dyest—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: My dear Julia, you are a Fool, my Love.—

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: For what, dear Husband?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I say, a silly Fool, to refuse the love of so Great a Turk; why, what a Pox makes you so coy?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: How! this from you, Francisco.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: — Now does my heart begin to fail me;— and yet, I shall ne'er indure strangling neither;— why, am not I your Lord and Master, hah?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Heavens! Husband, what wou'd you have me doe?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Have you doe;— why, I wou'd have ye— d'ye see,— twill not out;— why, I wou'd have ye— lie with the Sultan, huswife; I wonder how, the Devil, you have the face to refuse him, so hansom— so young a Lover; come, come, let me hear no more of your coyness, Mistress, for, if I do— I shall be hang'd;—
The Great Turk's a most worthy Gentleman, and therefore I advise you to doe as he advises you; and the Devil take ye both.—

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: This from my Husband, old Francisco! he advise me to part with my dear Honour!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Rather than part with his dear Life, I thank ye.—

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Have you consider'd the Vertue of a Wife?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: No, but I have consider'd the neck of a Husband.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: — Which Vertue, before I'll lose, I'll die a thousand deaths.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: So will not I, one; a Pox of her Vertue,— these women are always vertuous in the wrong place.
— I say, you shall be kind to the sweet Sultan.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: And rob my Husband of his right!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Shaw, exchange is no robbery.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: And forsake my Vertue, and make none Dear a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Shaw, most of the Heroes of the world were so;— go prethee Hony go— do me the favour to Cuckold me a little, if not for Love, for Charity.—

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Are you in earnest?—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I am.—

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: And, wou'd it not diplease you?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I say, no;— had it been Aquinius his Case, to have sav'd the pinching of his Gullet he wou'd have been a Cuckold—

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Fear has made you mad, or you're bewitcht;
and I'll leave you to recover your Wits again.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Oh, Gracious Wife, leave me not in despair; I am not mad, no, nor no more bewitcht than I have been these forty years; 'tis you're be witcht to refuse so hansom— so young, and so— a Pox on him, she'll ne'er relish me again, after him.
sp.stage: Kneels to her and holds her.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Since you've lost your honour with your wits, I'll try what mine will doe.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Oh! I am lost,— I'm lost— dear Wife,— most mighty Sir, I've brought her finely to't;— do not make me lose my credit with his Mahometan Grace,— my wife has a monstrous affection for your Honour, but, she's something bashsull; but, when alone your Magnanimiousness will find her a swinger.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: — Fair Creature—

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Do you believe my Husband, Sir, he's mad.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Dog.—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Hold mighty Emperor; as I hope to be sav'd 'tis but a copy of her countenance— inhumane Wife— lead her to your apartment Sir;—— barbarous honest woman,— to your chamber, Sir,— wou'd I had married thee an errand Strumpet; nay, to your Royal bed, Sir, I'll warrant you she gives you taunt for taunt: try her, Sir, try her.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Hark you, Sir, are you possest, or, is it real reformationin you? what mov'd this kind fit?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: E'en Love to sweet Life; and, I shall think my self ever oblieged, to my dear Wife, for this kind Reprieve;— had she been cruel— I had been strangled or hung in the Air like our Prophets Tomb.

sp.speaker: 1 Tu.
sp.p: Sir, boast the honour of the news I bring you.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Oh, my head! how my brows twinge!

sp.speaker: 1 Tu.
sp.p: The mighty Sultan, to doe you honour, has set your Daughter and her Lover free, ransomless;— and, this day, gives 'em liberty to solemnize the Nuptials in the Court;— but, Christian Cerimonies must be private; but you're to be admitted, and, I'll conduct you to 'em.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Some comfort, I shall be Father to a Vicount, and for the rest— Patience—
sp.l: All Nations Cuckolds breed, but I deny
They had such need of Cuckolding as I.

div.stage: Enter Antonio, and Clara to Jacinta.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Madam, the rarest sport— Ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: You need not tell us, we have been witness to all,
sp.l: But to our own affairs, my dearest Clara.
Let us not lose this blessed opportunity,
Which Art nor Industry can give again if this be idly lost.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Nay, hang me if it be Antonio, Charge it to the Number of your own sins; it shall not ly at my door.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: 'Tis generously said, and take notice, my little dear Virago, Guzman has a Priest ready to tye you to your word.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: As fast us you please; hang her that fears the Conjuring knot for me: But what will our Fathers say,— mine, who Expects me to be the Governor's Lady; and yours, who designs Isabella for a Daughter-in-law?

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Mine will be glad of the Change, and, for yours, if he be not pleas'd, let him keep his Portion to himself— that's the greatest mischeife he can do us: and for my friend, the Governour, he s above their anger.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Why do we lose precious time; I long to be at,— I Clara, take thee Antonio,— the very ceremony will be tedious, so much I wish thee mine; and each delay gives me a fear something will snatch me from thee.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: No power of man can do't, thou art so Guarded; but now the Priest is employd in Clapping up the honourable marrige between the False Count and Isabella.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Lord, what a jest 'twill be to see 'em Coupled, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Unmercyfull Antonio, to drive the jest so far; 'tis too unconscionable!

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p:
By Heav'n, I'm so proud I cannot think my Revenge sufficient for affionts, nor does her Birth, her Breeding and her Vanity— deserve a better Fortune; besides,— he has enough to set up for a Modern Spark— the Fool has just wit and good-manners sufficient to pass for a Fop of fashion; and, where he is not known, will gain the Reputation of a fine accomplisht Gentleman,
— yet I'm resolv'd she shall see him in his geers, in his original Filthiness, that my Revenge may be home upon the foolish Gilt.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Cruel Antonio,— come let's go give 'em joy.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: And finish our asfair with Mr Vicar.—
sp.stage: Enter Isabella, her train born by the great Page; Guiliom, with the other great Page, and Francisco, bare.
sp.p: — Joy to my Noble Lord, and you, fair Isabella!

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Thank thee, Fellow,— but, surely, I deserv'd my Titles from thee.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Your Honour, I hope, will Pardon him.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: How now Clara—

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I give your Honour joy.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Thank thee, poor Creature.—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: My Lord,— this Honour you have done my Daughter is so signall, that whereas, I design'd her but Five Thousand pound, I will this happy day— settle on her ten.—

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Damn dirty trash your Beauty is sufficient— hum— Seignior Don Antonio, get the Writings ready,— Money— hang money.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: How generous these Lords are; nay, my Lord, you must not refuse a Fathers love— if I may presume to call you son— I shall find enough besides for my Ransom, if the Tyrant be so unmercyfull to ask more than my Wife payes him.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Nay, if you— will force it upon me.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Ay, take it, the trifling some will serve to buy our Honour Pins.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Well, Sir, since you will force it on him, my Cashier shall draw the Writings.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: And have 'em sign'd by a publick Notary,—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: With all my Soul, Sir, I'll go give him order, and subscribe.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Let him make 'em strong and sure— you shall go halves.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: No, you will deserve it dearely, who have the Plague of such a Wife with it;— but harkye, Count— these goods of Fortune are not to be afforded you, without conditions.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Shaw, conditions, any conditions, Noble Antonio.

sp.speaker: Anto
sp.p: You must disrobe anon, and do'n your Native habiliaments— and in the Equipage give that fair Vicountess to understand the true quality of her Husband.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Hum— I'm afraid, 'tis a harder task to leap from a Lord to a Rogue, then tis from a Rogue to a Lord.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Not at all, we have Examples of both dayly.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I'll show you my agility— but, Sir,— I desire— I may Consummate, d'ye see,— Consummate,— a little like Lord, to make the marriage sure.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: You have the Freedom to doe so— the Writings I'll provide.—

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: I'll about it then, the Priest waites within sor you, and Guzman for you Jacinta,— haste, for he is to arrive anon Ambassador from Cadez.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I know not, this noise of Weddings has set me a gog, and I'll e'en in, and try what 'tis.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Come, Madam, your Honour and I have something else to doe— before I have fully dub'd you a Vicountess.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Ah Heav'ns, my Lord, what's that?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Why, a Certain Ceremony, which must be perform'd between a pair of Sheets,— but we'll let it a lone till Night.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Till night, no; whate'er it be, I wou'd not be without an Inch of that Ceremony, that may Compleat my Honour, for the World; no for Heav'ns sake let's retire, and Dub me presently.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Time enough, time enough.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: You love me not; that can deny me this.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Love— no— we are Married now, and people of our Quality never love after Marriage 'tis not great.—

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Nay, let's retire, and Compleat my Quality, and you will find me Wife a of the Mode I'll warrant you.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: For once you have prevail'd.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Whither away.—

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Onely to Consummate a little, pray keep your distance.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Consummate.—

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, that is to make me an absolute Vicountess— we cannot stay— farewell—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Hum— this Turkey Air has a notable Faculty, where the women are all plaguie kind.—

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: By Heav'n each Moment makes me more your slave—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: The business is done.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: My husband.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.p: — And all this constant love to old Francisco, has but ingag'd me more.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Ha, Love to me?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Sir, if this vertue, be but reall in you, how happy I shou'd be; but you'll relaps again and Tempt my vertue— which if you doe—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I'll warrant she wou'd kill her self.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: — I shou'd be sure to yield—

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: No, thou hast made an absolute Conquest o'er me— and if that Beauty tempt me every hour, I shall be still the same I was the last.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Pray Heav'n he be John.

sp.speaker: 1 Turk.
sp.p: Most Mighty Emperor, a Messenger from Cadez has Letters for your Highness.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Conduct him in; in this retreat of ours we use no State.

div.stage: Enter Guzman, as himself, gives Carlos Letters.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Don Carlos, Governour of Cadez greets your Highness.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: High and Mighty,
For seven Christian Slaves, taken lately by a Gally of yours, we offer you twice the Number of Mahometans taken from you by us,— if this suffice not,— propose your Ransoms, and they shall be paid by
Don Carlos Governour of Cadez.— Know you this Carlos offers so fair for you?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Most Potent Lord, I do, and wonder at the Complement,— and yet I am not jealous— I have so over act'd the Complesant Husband, that I shall never fall into the other Extreme again.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Go, let the Christian Governour understand his Request is granted.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: The slaves are ready, Sir, and a Gally to carry off the Christians.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: How shall we make this Governour amends?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I do even weep for joy; alas, I must leave it to thee Love!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: To me, Sir, do you mock me?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Mock thee, no; I know thy vertue, and will no more be jealous, beleive me Chickin I was an old Fool.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Your Wife is Chaste— she overcame my unruly passion with her Prayers and Tears.

div.stage: Enter Isabella, at one door; Clara, Antonio, Jacinta, at another; Isabellas Train carri'd up.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Rare News,— we are all free and ransom'd! All 〈◊〉 well and the man has his Mare again.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: You still forget your Duty and your distance.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: A Pox of your troublesom Honour; a man can't be overjoy'd in quiet for't.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: Sure I am not Mistaken, this is the House of my Son Antonio.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: Let it be whose house 'twill; I think the Devil's broke loose in't.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: — Or the Turks; for I have yet met with ne'er a Christian thing in't.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Hah,— Do I dream, or is that my Father-in-law, and Seignior Sebastian?

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: My Father here.—

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Baltazer—

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: Son, Francisco, why do you gaze on me so?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Bless me, Sir, are you taken by the great Turk too?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: Taken,— Great Turk,— what do you mean!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Mean, Sir; why, how the Devil came you into Turkey?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: Sure Jealousie has Crackt his Brains.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Crack me no Cracks, good Father mine;— am not I a Slave in Turkey? and is not this the Grand Seigniors Palace?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: So,— all will come out, there's no prevention.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: Some that are wiser answer us: You Son,— are you infected too?— was not yesterday to abeen your Wedding day?

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: To day has done as well, Sir, I have onely chang'd Isabella for Clara.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: How, Francisco, have you juggled with me?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: My Daughter's a Lady, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: And you Mistress; you have Marry'd Antonio, and left the Governour.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I thought him the fitter Match, Sir, and hope your Pardon.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: We cannot scape.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: But how came you hither, Gentlemen, and how durst you venture?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: Whither, Sir, to my own Son's house; is there such danger in coming a mile or two out of Cadez?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Is the Devil in you, or me, or both? Am not I in the Possession of Turks and Insidels?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: No, Sir; safe in Antonio Villa; within a League of Cadez.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Why, what a Pox, is not this the Great Turk himself?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: This, Sir;— cry mercy, my Lord— 'tis Don Carlos, Sir, the Governor.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: The Governor; the worst Great Turk of all; so, I am cozen'd,— most rarely cheated; why, what a horrid Plot's here carryed on, to bring in Heretical Cuckoldom?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Well, Sir, since you have found it out. I'll own my Passion.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Well, if I have been kind you forc't me 〈◊〉, nay Beg'd on your knees, to give my self away.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Guilty, guilty! I confess,— but 'twas to the Great Turk, Mistress, not Don Carlos.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: And was the sin the greater?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: No, but the Honour was less.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: Oh, horrid! What, intreat his Wife to be a Whore?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Sir, your mistaken, she was my Wife in sight of Heav'n before; and I but Seiz'd my own.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Oh,— Sir, she's at your Service still.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I thank you, Sir, and take her as my own.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: Hold, my Honour's concern'd.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Not at all, Father mine, she's my Wife, my Lumber now, and, I hope, I may dispose of my Goods and Chattels:— if he takes her we are upon equal terms, for he makes himself my Cuckold, as he has already made me his;— for, if my memory fail me not, we did once upon a time consummate, as my Daughter has it.

div.stage: Enter Guilion in his own dress, crying Chimney-Sweep.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Chimney-sweep,— by your leave, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Whither away, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: What's that to you, Sir?—

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Not to me, Sirrah;— who wou'd you speak with?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: What's that to you, Sir? why, what a Pox may not a man speak with his own Lady and Wife?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Heavens! his Wife! to look for his Wife amongst Persons of Quality!

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Kick out the Rascal.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: As soon as you please, my Lord; but, let me take my Wife along with me.

sp.speaker: Isa
sp.p: Faugh!— what means the Devil?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Devil;— 'twas not long since you found me a humane creature, within there.—

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Villain, Dog; help me to tear his eyes out.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: What, those eyes, those lovely eyes, that wounded you so deeply?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: What's the meaning of all this?— why, what, am I cozen'd? and is my Daughter cozen'd?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Cozen'd! why? I'm a man, Sir.—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: The Devil you are, Sir, how shall I know that?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Your Daughter does, Sir; and, that's all one.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Oh! I'm undone; am I no Vicountess then?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Hang Titles; 'twas my self you lov'd, my amiable sweet and charming self: in sine, sweet heart, I am your Husband; no Vicount, but honest Guilion the Chimney sweeper.— I heard your Father design'd to marry you to a Tradesman, and you were for a Don; and to please you both, you see how well I have manag'd matters.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I'll not give her a farthing.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: No matter, her love's worth a million; and, that's so great, that I'm sure she'll be content to carry my Soot-basket after me.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Ah! I dye, I dye.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: What, and I so kind?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Help; murther, murther!

div.stage: Goes and kisses her, and blacks her face.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Well, Gentlemen, I am something a better fortune than you believe me, by some thousands.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Substantial and good, faith, Sir, I know not where you'll find a better fortune for your Daughter as cases stand.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: And, for the Vicount, Sir; gay Cloths, Money and Confidence will set me up for one, in any ground in Christiandom.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, he's i'th' right; take him home to Sivil, your neighbours know him not, and he may pass for what you please to make him; the Fellow's honest, witty and hansom.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: — Well, I have consider'd the matter;— I was but a Leather-seller my self, and am grown up to a Gentleman; and, who knows but he, being a Chimney-sweeper, may, in time, grow up to a Lord; Faith, I'll trust to Fortune, for once— here— take her, and rid me of one Plague, as you, I thank you, Sir, have done of another.—

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Prethee, be pacified, thou shalt see me within this hour, as pretty a fluttering Spark as any's in Town.— my noble Lord,— I give you thanks and joy; for, you are happy too.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: As Love and Beauty can make me.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: And I, as no damn'd Wife, proud Daughter or tormenting Chamber-maid can make me.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: And I, as Heaven and Clara can.
— You base born Beauties, whose Ill manner'd Pride,
Th'industrious noble Citizens deride,
May you all meet with Isabella's Doom.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: — And, all such Husbands as the Count Guiliome.

div.head: EPILOGUE
div.p: Spoken by Mrs. Barry. Made by a Person of Quality.

lg.l: I Come not a Petitioner to sue,
This Play the Author has writ down to you;
'Tis a slight Farce, five days brought sorth with ease,
So very foolish that it needs must please;
For though each day good Judges take offence,
And Satyr Armes in Comedy's defence,
You are still true to your Jack Pudding Sense.
No 〈◊〉 can miss your Approbation,
You love it as you do a new French Fashion:
Thus in true hate of Sense, and Wit's despight,
Bantring and Shamming is your dear deligh:
Thus among all the follys here abounding,
None took like the new Ape-trick of Dumsounding.
If to make People laugh the business be,
You Sparks better Comedians are than we;
You every day out sool ev'n Nokes and Lee.
They 're forc'd to stop and their own Farces quit,
T' admire admire the Merry Andrews of the Pit;
But if your mirth so grate the Critique's ear,
Your Love will yet more Harlequin appear.
— You 〈◊〉 Grievance of the Boxes,
You wither'd Ruines of stain'd Wine and Poxes;
What strange Green sickness do you hope in Women
Shou'd make 'em love old fools in new point Linnen;
The Race of Life you run off-hand too sast,
Your fiery Mettle is too hot to last;
Your Feavers come so thick, your claps so plenty,
Most of you are threescore at five and twenty.
〈◊〉 town 〈◊〉 I 〈◊〉 know you 〈◊〉 enough,
Your courting Women's like your taking Snuss;
Out of meer Idleness you keep a 〈◊〉,
You've no more need of one than of the other.
Ladyes—
Wou'd you be quit of their insipid noise,
And vain pretending, take a fool's advice;
Of the faux Braves I 've had some little trial,
There's nothing gives 'em credit but denyal:
As when a Coward will pretend to Hussing.
Offer to sight, away sneaks Bully-Russin.
So when these Sparks, whose business is addressing,
In Love pursuites grow troublesome and pressing.
When they affect to keep still in your eye,
When they send Grisons every where to spye,
And full of Coxcomb dress and Ogle high;
Seem to receive their Charge, and face about,
I 'll pawn my life they never stand it out.
